In 1913, the International Association of Fire Engineers (now the International Association of Fire Chiefs) held their 41st annual conference in New York City.  One component of the event was a competition for the newly developed motorized pumper.  On September 3 at 6:30 a.m., the 12-hour pump test began with 11 pieces of apparatus competing.  A length of hard suction hose was used by each engine to draft water from the Hudson River.  

Overall performance of the equipment was determined by using a point system.  The motor had to remaining running during the complete 12-hour test period.

Apparatus from the following companies began the event.

Ahrens-Fox
American LaFrance - Two units
Knox
Luietweiler
Nott - Two units  
Robinson - Two units
Seagrave
Waterous

Eight of the engines completed the test.  The Luietweiler, one Nott and one Robinson failed.  The Ahrens-Fox earned the highest score.

In addition to this information, I have added a few notes to some of the other photos in this grouping.

In this photo: The two Nott fire engines that participated are pumping.

Probably this:

“PUMPING CASCADES FOR THE FIRE CHIEFS
Motor Apparatuses Draw 6,000,000 gallons form the Hudson Demonstrating Efficiency”
WOMEN MOVED TO TEARS

The world’s Fire Chiefs who are here attending the forty-first annual convention and fire exposition of the International Association of Fire Engineers, spent the whole of yesterday making observations at a capacity test of motor fire pumps on the pier at Fifty-fourth Street and the North River.  To the thousands of residents who went to De Witt Clinton Park, overlooking the pier, the test must have appeared like an attempt to pump the Hudson River dry.”

NEW YORK TIMES   September 4, 1913
Nice detective work, puzzlemaster! This must be the event. I've found licence plates on the engines in other photos for Miss. and Minn., suggesting that it was a nationwide exposition.

The schedule for the event is described in NYT of August 3, 1913 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A04EFDD113BE633A... (Don't be confused by headline and first paragraph. Like Cassies grandma, I was intrigued by the "tall ship." I think it might be a coal schooner or similar east coast freighter. See pressherald.mainetoday.com/specialrpts/shipbuilding/story... for a picture of a very similar vessel, the Paul Palmer. It can't be the Paul Palmer, because she caught fire and sank off Cape Cod earlier in 1913. But apparently there was a fleet of such vessels. www.fishermensvoice.com/archives/mar01.html#bigger has a 2001 article about building such schooners in Maine. www.ahrtp.com/TallshipsOnLine/pages/PALMER1.htm is another picture of the Paul Palmer (being launched in Waldoboro, Maine in 1902)

William Jay Gaynor had served a term as reform mayor of New York. Because the incorruptible Gaynor would not cooperate with the Tammany machine, Tammany refused to nominate him for a second term. So Gaynor was renominated by an independent group, and accepted their nomination. In this photo, the independents are on their way to notify Gaynor of the nomination, just before he sailed to Europe on a vacation voyage. On September 10, exactly a week after this photo was taken, Gaynor died of a heart attack, in his deck chair aboard the steamship Baltic, 400 miles off the coast of Ireland.

It seems to be part of the mayoral election campaign of 1913. The notification ceremonies took place on 3rd September 1913. William Gaynor, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Gaynor was nominated for mayor by a group of independent supporters after clashing with the Democrats over corruption in office. He died a few days after this on 10th September 1913. The C. F. M. of the placard will be Charles F Murphy, the boss of Tammany Hall.
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_F._Murphy

Thanks to all for your helpful information. We will expand the description for this photograph as well as others from the Sept. 3, 1913 Gaynor notification ceremony. The notification ceremony was Gaynor accepting the nomination for re-election as New York's mayor on an independent ticket. The shovel was a symbol of his campaign, and this photograph shows the shovels carried by his supporters surrounding an epitaph of sorts to the election hopes of Charles F. Murphy. More about this day can be found in this article from the New York Times.
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chauncey_Depew

William H. Fitzpatrick was chairman of the Erie County (Buffalo, N.Y.) Democratic Committee. On June 16, 1913, Fitzpatrick refused to influence the votes of legislators from his district in favor of a bill backed in the New York legislature by Governor William Sulzer (who was about to be impeached).

In 1912, a New York Times article referred to Fitzpatrick as (Tammany boss Charles F.) "Murphy's chief lieutenant in western New York." (NYT, 3/13/1912.)

Elizabeth Amsden died on July 19, 1966 (see her obituary in the July 21, 1966 New York Times (as Mrs. G. Chaminadas)). Her obituary lists her sister as Mrs. Walter MacCornack, That information led to their parents names (Elbridge Frank and Algina Ida Amsden) and the family's entry in the 1900 census. In the census, the couple's daughter Hattie J. Amsden is listed as a vocalist. I believe Elizabeth Amsden was born Hattie Josephine Amsden on October 9, 1881 (familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.1.1/F4YY-4BF)..

Harry Kendall Thaw fled to Canada in 1913. William Lewis Shurtleff was his lawyer for the extradition at this courthouse. Thaw had murdered Stanford White because White had had sex with Evelyn Florence Nesbit before she became Thaw's wife. Nesbit at the trial described the intimate relationship with White including the velvet swing he kept in one of his apartments. The story was fictionalized in Ragtime.

rjones0856:

It does make you wonder why the Bain News Service wrote 'Suffragettes' on this photograph, while we have no visual evidence they are actually suffragettes, and more evidence they are simply marching in a Labor Day parade as members of a union.  Hard to say if this is an assumption made by the original captioner or if it was based on some other piece of information we do not have.

There's something I don't understand about this picture:  how come the barge on the right of the image has a mast and sail erected?  To reach this location, surely it must have passed under several low bridges.  Can anyone suggest an explanation?

Looking at these and other images of the Oudegracht in former times, I almost regret that today we have all those tall trees obscuring the view of these elegant canals, bridges and buildings.  And I really like trees!
I guess the mast can be pulled down, otherwise it's impossible to get there indeed...

Well, yes, it makes sense that the mast can be dismantled, but why erect it again at this point?  No sailing to be done here.

Maybe erecting the mast was the best way to keep it out of the way when loading and unloading.  Still, I'd be curious to hear from anyone who knows about these barges and how they worked.

The Scheveningseweg is a long, straigh road, designed bij Constantijn Huygens in 1653. The road connects the old centre of The Hague and the fisherman's village Scheveningen on the coast. 
It is the first paved road in Holland outside cities built-up areas. Construction of this new 'Zee-straet van 's Gravenhaghe op Schevening' (seastreet from The Hague to Scheveningen) was finished in 1665.

An 1880 article describes the isolated fishing island that Marken will have been when these photos were taken. "The men are extraordinarily sober, and live to a great age. They leave the island every Sunday night with their boats, pass the week fishing in the Zuyder Zee, and return on the Saturday. The women educate the children, cultivate the ground, and make the clothing for the family. Like all the other Dutch women, they love cleanliness and ornament, and in their cabins also are to be seen the inevitable white curtains, glass cups, embroidered bed-covers, looking-glasses, and flowers. The greater part of them never see any other land than that of their little island. " See www.oldandsold.com/articles19/holland-14.shtml After the Afsluitdijk dam closed the Zuiderzee and formed the Ijsselmeer, Marken was joined to the mainland by a causeway in 1957. See islas.ruudbijlsma.nl/mk_en.htm

In the time that The Hague was still beautiful. A lot has been destroyed in the 2nd WW, and the rest they destroyed in the last 20 years.

Actually you could probably take the same photo today and it would look largely the same. The city hall building and the church in the foreground on the left are still there and the pavement has been restored to something resembling what's in the picture, too.

iljitsch is right. And Moustache-Man also, but he's wrong with the causes of destruction. The most beautiful parts of theHague, my home town, has been destroyed between 1900 en 1930. And later, in the 60 and early 70's.

Yes - this spot is still very recognisable today. The Hague really hasn't come off lightly with destruction. Have to say that it is the stuff of the last 20 years that has been the ugliest ! ( Sorry city planners  - but who thought that huge wind tunnel avenue in front of the station was a good idea ?? )

In my opinion, it was mainly the "stadsvernieuwing" ("city renewal") of the 1980s that produced very ugly results. Just look at the Schilderswijk. Starting with the 1990s newer buildings at least had some esthetics, although that doesn't necessarily make them beautiful.

Although most of the canals are gone and The Hague doesn't have big stretches of really old stuff like Delft or even Amsterdam, there's still plenty of good stuff around, including some 19th / early 20th century neighborhoods, for instance:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/iljitsch/4135014469/sizes/s/]
Now the Old City Hall (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_City_Hall_%28The_Hague%29) Similar modern view: www.panoramio.com/photo/19995951

This is the Gemeenlandshuis of Delfland or Huyterhuis: Around 1505 the house of the very wealthy Jan de Huyter, he was chairman of the polder board of Delft, was furnished with a façade of natural stone and a tower. In the 16th century the so-called Huyter House was the richest house of Delft. It was situated at Oude Delft 167. After the house of the Spanish minded grandchild Jan de Huyter had been forfeited in 1572, it was used during five years by the Hof of Holland. Since then different owners came and went amongst whom the city of Delft. In1645 the Huyterhuis was bought by the Hoogheemraadschap of Delfland (Polder Authorities). The front façade is decorated with numerous little monsters and hop bells. The tower has a beautifully gilded weathervane which depicts a mermaid. The actual town hall is in the next picture.

Now known as the Morspoort (Marsh Gate). Fortunately not demolished.

Built in 1668 as one of the original 10 old city gates of Leiden city, the Morspoort, or Marsh Gate, is only one of 2 that exist today. It still looks identical to this print, but the fence to the right no longer stands. Nowadays, traffic - except pedestrians and bicyclists - is directed around the gate. The Morspoort used to be called Gallows Gate since its road lead the the gallow field but it was renamed shortly after to Morspoort because of the nearby marshes. There are still 2 roads called Galgewater (Gallow's water) on each side of a canal. View also www.360cities.net/image/morspoort-leiden-the-netherlands

'koren' in dutch is 'wheat' in english 'corn' would have been 'mais' in dutch. this is a common mistake but please relabel your text

The confusion goes back to the so-called Corn Laws in England in 1832, which actually regulated what Americans called "wheat." At that time, American corn (as in corn on cobs), or maize, was virtually unknown in England.

Incidentally, "cob," as in cobweb, was another name for a spider -- but that's a whole different can of worms . . . .

According to the OED, corn has meant seed or grain in English as far back as the 9th century, but it tends to refer to different grains in different regions.

"As a general term the word includes all the cereals, wheat, rye, barley, oats, maize, rice, etc., and, with qualification (as black corn, pulse corn), is extended to leguminous plants, as pease, beans, etc., cultivated for food. Locally, the word, when not otherwise qualified, is often understood to denote that kind of cereal which is the leading crop of the district; hence in the greater part of England ‘corn’ is = wheat, in North Britain and Ireland = oats; in the U.S. the word, as short for Indian corn, is restricted to maize."

Dit is de buurtschap Smitshoek, gelegen bij de kruising van de Zuidendijk en de Smitsweg in de toen nog zelfstandige gemeente Dubbeldam. Deze buurtschap bestond uit een smederij, een wagenmakerij, wat boerderijen met bijbehorende daglonerhuisjes en een enkel winkeltje. De belangrijkste zaken voor een agrarische gemeenschap waren dus aanwezig. De smid voorzag de paarden uit de buurt van nieuwe hoefijzers en samen met de wagenmaker zorgde hij in het tijdperk voor de mechanisatie voor de landbouwwerktuigen. Uit tekeningen die leden van het tekengenootschap Pictura zoals Johannes van Lexmond hier maakten, blijkt dat er kort na 1800 al een smid gevestigd was. De travalje, waarin de paarden werden beslagen, heeft er tot na de Tweede Wereldoorlog gestaan. Van het negatief gaf de Dordtse boekhandelaar J. de Zeeuw in 1899 een zwart-wit prentbriefkaart uit. Het dorp Dubbeldam werd in 1970 door de stad Dordrecht geannexeerd.

From wikipedia: SS Imperator was an ocean liner built for the Hamburg America Line (German: Hamburg-Amerikanische Packetfahrt-Actien-Gesellschaft or HAPAG) launched in 1912. She was the first of a trio of successively larger Hamburg America ships that included SS Vaterland and SS Bismarck built by the line for transatlantic passenger service. At the time of her launch in May 1912, she was the largest passenger ship in the world superseding the RMS Olympic. During World War I, the ship remained in port in Hamburg. After the war she was briefly commissioned into the United States Navy as USS Imperator (ID-4080) and employed for returning American troops from Europe. Following her U.S. Navy service, Imperator was handed over to Britain's Cunard Line as part of war reparations, and she sailed as the flagship RMS Berengaria for the final decade of her career. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Imperator

Uncorrupted Democratic Boss of Cook County, Illinois (Chicago), returning at the end of August, 1913, from a four-month trip to South America and Europe, with his wife and daughter and a few political cronies. He was greeted on his arrival (via the Lusitania) at the Cunard docks by a mob of Chicago-area officeholders, who dined with him in his rooms at New York City's Waldorf Astoria hotel. "Chicago Men Here to Greet Sullivan," story in New York Times, August 29, 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E0CE6DC113CE6... Sullivan Interviewed: New York Times story, August 30, 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9D04E3DC113CE6... A brief story in the New York Times, September 7, 1913, reported that Sullivan's friends were boosting him for a U. S. Senate campaign. [He did run for the Senate in 1914, but was defeated.]: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9803E4D9113BE6...

This was the International Association of Fire Chiefs convention from September 1, 1913 to September 6, 1913 in New York City, New York. It was held in 1914 in New Orleans and several of the fire chiefs are wearing the pennant for upcoming event. They have exchanged pennants so they have them from multiple cities pinned to their coats.  There is an error in that George O. Luce was listed as from Knoxville, but he was the fire chief of Utica, New York. Samuel Becket Boyd II (March 20, 1865 - March 29, 1929) was the fire chief of Knoxville, Tennessee who died in the line of duty in 1929. He was president of the International Association of Fire Chiefs in 1924. Wystan is correct in that they also attended the Firemen's Memorial dedication during the convention.

AH Runge was fire marshal of the State of Dakota in the 1910s. George Consider Hale (1850-1923) was fire chief in Kansas City (1882-1902), and an inventor of fire safety equipment. Joseph Johnson was Fire Commissioner in New York City, 1911-1913: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Johnson_(FDNY_Commissioner)
The Firemen's Memorial in Riverside Park, New York, was dedicated on September 5, 1913. These men were part of the national delegation in attendance on that occasion.

Roamer was a bay gelding foaled in 1911, bred by the Clay Brothers  in Kentucky. 

He was named Roamer due to the circumstaces of his birth. It was an accidental breeding - somehow, the farm's 'teaser' stallion (a stallion of low value used to test if mares are in heat, who is rarely used for actual breeding), aptly named Knight Errant, got in with a blind mare named Rose Tree II. 

After being claimed at age two by owner Andrew Miller, Roamer began to blossom. He raced from 1913 to 1919, winning 39 of 98 races.  His best year was 1914, when he won 12 of 16 starts and was the year's leading money earner.  He set five track records and won many notable races, including the Travers Stakes, Carter Handicap, and three Saratoga Cups. Some press accounts called him "The Wonder Horse of the Decade".

Roamer died in 1920. While being rested on a farm in New Jersey, he slipped in an icy pasture, broke his leg, and had to be destroyed. He was inducted to the Racing Hall of Fame in 1981.

This photo pre-dates Roamer's fame - in fact, it shows the day his fortunes changed. The jockey here is Thomas McTaggart. The only time he ever rode Roamer was in a claiming race at Belmont Park on July 15, 1913.  They won, "much the best", by four lengths, and Miller claimed him for $2,000.  He would go on to earn $98,828.

Thanks for making my day !

Have a great weekend my dear friend!

From wikipedia: SS Imperator was an ocean liner built for the Hamburg America Line (German: Hamburg-Amerikanische Packetfahrt-Actien-Gesellschaft or HAPAG) launched in 1912. She was the first of a trio of successively larger Hamburg America ships that included SS Vaterland and SS Bismarck built by the line for transatlantic passenger service. At the time of her launch in May 1912, she was the largest passenger ship in the world superseding the RMS Olympic. During World War I, the ship remained in port in Hamburg. After the war she was briefly commissioned into the United States Navy as USS Imperator (ID-4080) and employed for returning American troops from Europe. Following her U.S. Navy service, Imperator was handed over to Britain's Cunard Line as part of war reparations, and she sailed as the flagship RMS Berengaria for the final decade of her career. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Imperator

The slogan on the globe reads: "Mein Feld ist die Welt" (My Domain is the World), the well-known motto of HAPAG founder Albert Ballin. 

The words rhyme in German.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/15283643@N04/4101365085/]

Edward E. McCall, former Justice of the Supreme Court [of New York] and later Chairman of the Public Service Commission. He ran unsuccessfully as the Democratic party candidate for the Mayor of New York City in 1913. The New York Times in 1916: Supreme Court Justice Giegerich yesterday appointed Edward E. McCall, former Justice of the Supreme Court and later Chairman of the Public Service Commission, receiver for the Madison Square Garden. Bond was furnished in $200,000. Source: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E03E7DD1131E733A... I added him to Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Everett_McCall

There's a calendar on the wall behind him, but the month on it is inscrutable. I think it is safe to assume that the photo was circulated in connection with the announcement of his mayoralty candidacy in August, 1913.
Thanks Richard.  We'll fill in his name the next time we update the record.

LOC:  Keep in mind that in New York, the Supreme Courts (each county has one) are trial courts of general jurisdiction, like the Superior Courts in other jurisdictions.  Referring to the subject by his early-career (1903-13) judicial post isn't really accurate, especially since this picture, and the others in the Bain Collection, show him in his post as Chairman of the New York State Public Services Commission, a higher statewide post.  I think referring to him as a judge and politician is a better general description.

Daughter of New York Supreme Court justice Edward Everett McCall (1863-1924) and his wife, the former Ella F. Gaynor.  In 1913, Edward Everett McCall was appointed by the governor to the Public Service Commission.  in 1914, Edward Everett McCall was running for mayor of New York City, with Tammany Hall backing.  In 1915 Constance was a maid of honor at her sister Ella's wedding to William R. Maloney.  In 1924, she's still listed as Miss Constance McCall in obituaries following her father's passing.

Wystan, your description of McCall's namesake, Edward Everett, as a "windbag" is consistent with modern conventional wisdom but is historically inaccurate.  He was considered the finest American orator at a time when keynote speakers at such momentous events as the dedication of the Gettysburg Cemetery were expected to speak for a couple of hours.  It was Lincoln who jarred the crowd by uttering a few words, then sitting back down before the audience had settled in.  Many who were present thought that Lincoln, in his brevity, showed disrespect to the occasion.  Most journalists covering the event dismissed Lincoln's speech as a sidenote hardly worthy of mention (Lincoln was, after all, a last minute invitee to the event; Everett was the advertised keynote speaker).  Only when Lincoln's speech was reprinted as a circular did the public come to realize the brilliance of his words.  Thus, only in hindsight, do we look back at Lincoln and Everett on that day and dismiss Everett as the "windbag."  The folks who saw them speak at Gettyburg that day saw it very differently.
True, and most in the crowd who went that day to see the great men were unable to hear the utterances of either of them.

Pince-nez type eyeglasses were the most popular eyewear in the USA, Canada and much of Europe during the period 1885 to 1920. A pince-nez had no arms or temples and clipped on the bridge of the nose. It was held in place by either spring powered nose guard grips in the fingerpiece type or a spring bridge with nose guard grips in the hoopspring or C bridge type. Properly fitted and adjusted to each individual, a pince-nez remained securely attached to the bridge of the nose at all times and was very comfortable even during full time wear. Eyeglasses (pince-nez) and spectacles (glasses with temples) : were unisex then. The terms eyeglasses and spectacles had distinct meanings. The rimless pince-nez was the most popular and stylish for all ages. For soldiers,it was great for wear under a gas mask or goggles and army officials stated the a pince-nez was the ideal eyewear. 
See pincenez1.blospot.com Pince-nez Renaissance blog/site the only place on the web or anywhere for very detailed,accurate info re: pince-nez.Click on table of contents. Many of the photos can be enlarged by clicking on them. The site encourages people to wear a pince-nez.

On July 2, 1913, John Henry Mears left New York City on the Mauritania, then took a combination of steamers, yachts, and trains (and a Hydroplane!) to circle the globe before returning to New York on August 6, 1913--"the fastest man to travel Round-the-World." His record remained for thirteen years. He was also a theatrical producer and lyricist. There's a while chapter about him in Carrol V. Glines, Round-the-World Flights (Brassey's Inc 2003). He wrote about his adventure in Racing the Moon (1928). www.wingnet.org/rtw/RTW001B.HTM www.ibdb.com/person.php?id=13105

Kids here in Ann Arbor used to do stuff like this sixty years ago -- probably still do. It was a service of the parks system, called "Supervised Play," and for mere pennies we could weave potholders by stringing elastic cotton loops across a grid of nails, or braid raffia into lanyards. (Our "raffia" came in a selection of bright colors, and was made of some kind of synthetic, plasticized material). We ended up with segments of lanyards that never got finished: the same kind of project that the poet Billy Collins wrote about in his wonderful poem, "The Lanyard," in which he describes one he fashioned as a boy in an Adirondak summer camp: "this useless, worthless thing I wove out of boredom." I think the point is that this dollhouse did not belong to any one girl.  

1) You could put something like this out in public without "protection" and it would still be there months later.  

2) I'm guessing that if any child broke a piece, the parents would see that it was replaced - probably making the replacement by hand.

3) Kids knew how to SHARE, meaning that kids did not personally own more than a handful of toys at any given time...probably not much more than they could physically carry around with them.

No way was this left outside without protection. The dollhouse was part of a supervised playground activity, and the supervisor (an adult, of at least high school age, who may have been a volunteer, but probably was paid) would have locked it and its contents inside the shed at day's end.

I think the "haunted house" was a 20-room country home named Elmhurst Grange, located in Munster Township, PA [1] and also referred to as located in Loretto, PA [2] – both of which are next-door to the mis-captioned Cresson, PA.  Elmhurst was built by William and Mary Thaw, parents of Harry Thaw. Evelyn Nesbit Thaw reportedly stayed there a few times. The castle home in the above photograph was named Lyndhurst – the Gothic Revival home of William and Mary C. Thaw – and wasn't near Cresson, but was located at 1165 Beechwood Boulevard, in the Squirrel Hill section of Pittsburgh, PA.[3] [4]   William Thaw (1818-1889) was a founder of the Pennsylvania railroad. It was named "Lyndhurst" for a Tarrytown, N.Y., home owned by fellow railroad magnate Jay Gould.[5]  [See: "Gould's home, Tarrytown" /LOC]
"It was designed by architect Theophilus Parsons Chandler, and construction began in 1887. William Thaw's widow, Mary Thaw, later sold part of the property to raise funds for her son Harry's legal defense. Harry K. Thaw was arrested for murdering prominent architect Stanford White in 1906." – Squirrel Hill - Images of America, The Squirrel Hill Historical Society, Arcadia Publishing, 2005.
Lyndhurst was then bought by industrialist Emil Winter (1857-1941), a prominent banker and a founder of the Pittsburgh Steel Co., who extensively remodeled the home. Lyndhurst was demolished c.1942. [6]

In August 1913, three men were killed and 62 others trapped in a tunnel in Harlem, part of the Catskill Aqueduct, when a fire started in a blacksmith's shop at the head of the shaft. It was especially dangerous because 900 pounds of dynamite were stored in the tunnel. There was no light, no fresh air, and a lot of smoke, but eventually the trapped men were rescued.

Robert F. Wagner (1877-1953), longtime US Senator from New York, served as acting lieutenant governor under Martin H. Glynn in 1913-1914, after the impeachment of William Sulzer. Born in Prussia, immigrated to the US as a boy with his parents. That's probably meant to be Mrs. Charles DeLoosey Oelrichs, a prominent member of Newport society and a member of the Congressional Union for Woman Suffrage too. She married Charles DeLoosey Oelrichs (1882-1973), a stockbroker, in 1907, and they were divorced in 1921. They had one child, daughter Margery (aka Marjorie, aka "Bubbles"); maybe that's her in the photo. If it is, she eventually married Eddy Duchin, the bandleader, in 1935, and became mother to Peter Duchin (b. 1937). Marjorie Oelrichs Duchin died two days after the birth of Peter. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marjorie_Oelrichs en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eddy_Duchin en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Duchin

The Oelrichs seem like a complicated family with a lot of same-named people; Margery/Marjorie Oelrichs, daughter of the Charles DeLoosey Oelrichs, was born after 1907, which would seem to make her a little younger than this child.

Pince-nez type eyeglasses were the most popular eyewear in the USA, Canada and much of Europe during the period 1885 to 1920. A pince-nez had no arms or temples and clipped on the bridge of the nose. It was held in place by either spring powered nose guard grips in the fingerpiece type or a spring bridge with nose guard grips in the hoopspring or C bridge type. Properly fitted, a pince-nez remained securely attached to the bridge of the nose at all times and was very comfortable even during full time wear. Eyeglasses (pince-nez) and spectacles (glasses with temples) : were unisex then. The terms eyeglasses and spectacles had distinct meanings. The rimless type was the most popular and stylish for all ages. For soldiers,it was great for wear under a gas mask or goggles and army officials stated the a pince-nez was the ideal eyewear. 
See Pince-nez Renaissance blog/site the only place on the web or anywhere for very detailed,accurate info re: pince-nez.Click on table of contents. Many of the photos can be enlarged by clicking on them.
pincenez1.blogspot.com

Probably Reginald F. Del Valle, in summer 1913, a Special Commissioner of the American State Department to Mexico according to NYT, August 5, 1913 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D01E4DF123FE633A...

From Google cache of southwest.library.arizona.edu/true/body.1_div.11.html CHAPTER XI: HON. REGINALD F. DEL VALLE To define a gentleman one might go far afield without disclosing a more pronounced exemplar than is Hon. Reginald F. del Valle, eldest son of Don Ygnacio and Señora del Valle, who of all the human documents yet living is most readily identified as the person Mrs. Jackson had in mind in the idealization of the character of Felipe in the romance. Attire him in Spanish garb, as the artist Henry Sandham has properly done, and the portraits are not wholly unlike. Senator del Valle left Camulos ranch early in life to prepare himself for the practice of law, a profession he has graced for a quarter of a century in Los Angeles. Without undue self-seeking upon his part he has during that period been honored with many positions of distinction and trust. He always has been a consistent and active member of the Democratic [page 103] party, ever prominent in its councils, and not infrequently called upon to preside over its state conventions. Once he was a candidate for Lieutenant-Governor of California, at another time he served a term with great credit in the State Senate, securing for Los Angeles the State Normal school, and again was a delegate to the national convention of his party. At this time he is serving the City of Los Angeles in the honorary position of a member of the Municipal Water Board, a most important post during the period of bringing the Owens River to the city's gate. It was understood that, in the event of the election of Mr. Bryan, in 1896, Senator del Valle was to have the post of Ambassador to Mexico. It is an interesting circumstance, in this connection, that the romance of Mrs. Jackson closes with the arrival and settlement of Felipe and his beautiful bride in the Mexican capital. Of this the author says: ‘‘The story of the romance of their lives, being widely rumored, greatly enhanced the interest with which they were welcomed. The beautiful young Señora Moreno was the theme of the city; and Felipe's bosom thrilled with pride to see the gentle dignity of demeanor by which she was distinguished in all assemblages.’’ [page 104] In the spring of 1913 affairs throughout the Republic of Mexico were in such chaotic condition, owing to the movements of various revolutionary bodies, that the Administration at Washington felt impelled to withhold recognition of the provisional government represented by General Huerta until reliable assurances could be given of its ability to maintain a stable government and to give adequate protection to the lives and property of all classes of people. That dependable information might be obtained from the various opposing factions in the republic, President Wilson determined to send a personal representative into Mexico, to report such facts as might be developed directly to him, to the end that such action as might finally be taken by the government of the United States should be based upon indisputable facts, gathered by a person wholly disinterested. The mission was a peculiarly delicate one, calling for the highest order of intelligence, of tact and diplomacy. That the distinction should fall upon Hon. Reginald Francisco del Valle, of California, was not calculated to surprise anyone, since his entire fitness for the trust was and is universally recognized. Senator del Valle, his wife and daughter accompanying him, went to Mexico, and at this writing he is in the City of Mexico, performing the duty assigned him by the President of the United States.

Here is a nice biography of him from Who's Who in the Pacific Southwest: a compilation of authentic biographical sketches of citizens of Southern California from 1913: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/richard_arthur_norton/4023197736/] I also added him to Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reginald_F._Del_Valle

For some unknown reason i became a Giant fan in 1947 at the tender age of 13. 
There was a baseball board game called All Star Baseball Game,made by Cadaco Inc. 
The boys in my neighborhood could afford the $i.50 it took to buy the game buy selling soft drink bottles for 2cents apiece back to the mom and pop grocery stores,and pooling our money.
I think there were 5 of us kids. I picked last from the roster of major league stars.
All the big names had been picked.Babe Ruth,Lou Gehrig,Joe Dimaggio,Stan Musial and Ted Williams. 
The one player that was left that i really thought looked pretty good was Johnny Mize. He was a giant and i not only picked him but every other Giant player in that board game. 
My catchers were Roger Bresnahan,and Walker Cooper. Joining Mize at first base was Bill Terry. Frankie Frisch was at 2nd. Fred Lindstrom was at the hot corner,and my outfield was Bobby Thomson,Willard Marshall,and for some reason i cant remeber the other or my shortstop.
Christy Mathewson and Carl Hubbell headed my pitching staff.
It was a mixture of all time greats and current 1947 stars.
That 1947 year the real Giants finished 5th. Then in '48 they were 4th. 1949 saw them in 3rd and 1950 they were second to the Phillies whiz Kids.
1951 was my year. At the end of that season the Giants were tied for first with the hated Dodgers.
Then in the last playoff game Bobby Thomson hit the homerun that sent them to the worls series.
I hope you enjoyed my trip down memory lane.

Ball Manufacturing of Muncie, Indiana, makers of the iconic Ball jar, used in home canning of fruits and vegetables for well over a century.  The Ball brothers located their glass making company there due to the abundance of natural gas below ground, which is used in the glass making process.  Since its founding, the factory has recruited workers from the rural areas of Kentucky, Tennessee, and the surrounding areas presumably because they would work for lower wages.  I think that may account for the pipe smoking and gun toting seen in this photo.

The Ball brothers also put down the cash to start Ball State University in Muncie.  Because their sister had been blackballed by an Ivy League sorority back east, one of their conditions of founding was that there be no national sororities affiliated with the campus, a policy which still stands.

Photography, like anything, is about more than one thing. I most appreciate its singular ability to capture moments in time. To think, these boys, way back in 1908, gathered together for this group portrait. Then, once the shutter was squeezed off, they went back about their business, knowing neither what awaited them in life nor that the captive moment would be revisited countless times in the future.

John Montgomery Ward (March 3, 1860 – March 4, 1925) was an American Major League Baseball star pitcher, shortstop and manager.[1][2] Ward was born in Bellefonte, Pennsylvania, and grew up in Renovo, Pennsylvania.[3] He later successfully challenged the player reserve clause, leading to the formation of a new baseball league, the Players' League.  Ward retired from baseball at age 34 in order to enter the legal profession. As a successful lawyer he represented baseball players against the National League. Later he acted as president and part-owner of the Boston Braves franchise and became an official in the short lived Federal League in 1914, acting a the business manager of the Brooklyn Tip-Tops.[3]

Germans had been in the country in large numbers for a hundred years, from the East throughout the midwest and elsewhere. Japanese were more recent arrivals, more frequently found in the west where there was a greater fear (and evidence of) Japanese efforts to launch attacks on our homeland. Manzanar is not a proud footnote in US history, but easier to understand in context.

The reason the Japanese were rounded up was that they looked "different".....most Americans looked like they could be German.  Germans were as much a threat, if not more, to America as they had far superior  ships and submarines compared to the Japanese.  There were far more American CIvil Defense volunteers watching the East coast than there were on the West.  

So, yes, the German Americans indeed formed a large, established part of America by the early '40s.  But, there was no excuse to place Japanese Americans in these camps.  After all, they were American citizens who were taxpayers.  It was also incredible that those who were in these camps were never given any compensation until their families received $20,000 in the 1980s.  Why did they have to wait so long?

The collision actually took place during the first game of a July 5, 1924 doubleheader with the Senators: www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1924/B07051WS11924.htm Per p. 23 of the July 6, 1924 New York Times: [It] happened in the fourth inning, when Babe made a valiant effort for a long foul from Joe Judge’s bat, which just sailed over the wall into the crowded seats. The Babe ran into the pavilion parapet with the full force of his body, and dropped unconscious to the grass. Uniformed policemen ran to his assistance and kept back the crowd that seemed disposed to leave the chairs and get a close-up of the injured warrior. Several photographers happened to be on the spot and snapped the Babe as Trainer Doc Woods ran up with the water bucket and the little black bag of first aid preparations. At first it was thought that Ruth had been knocked out by a blow from the concrete on his chin, but it was soon discovered that he had been knocked out by a jolt in the solar plexus. His left leg was also hurt at the hip. [Yankee manager Miller] Huggins wanted Ruth to quit, but he insisted upon staying in, and got a double in the sixth…

Visible just below the policeman's outstretched arm is Yankee center fielder Whitey Whitt,  leaning against the outfield wall.  Whitt was the Yankees' opening day CF that season but lost his job when talented Earle Combes was acquired after the season started.  After a torrid .400 BA start, Combes broke his ankle in June and Whitt was reinstated as the CF'er for the rest of the season.

Whitey Whitt's real name was Ladislaw Waldemar Wittkowski.  Unlike most players of his day, Whitt was a college boy, having attended Bowdoin College.  He was also no stranger to the perils of playing the outfield.  Two seasons before the Babe's felling in Washington, Whitt himself was put down by a bottle thrown by a Browns' fan the day the Yankees clinched the 1922 pennant  in St. Louis.

After initially offering a one thousand dollar reward for the fingering of the perpetrator, American League president Ban Johnson abruptly changed course when St. Louis fans threatened a riot.  Johnson announced that Whitt had stepped on the bottle while running in CF and that the bottle had flipped up, striking him in the head and knocking him out!

The Perfessor was a hero in Brooklyn long before you were ever born.  He last PLAYED in Brooklyn in 1917 and last managed Brooklyn in 1936.  After that, he was no longer a hero in Brooklyn unless your family were somehow Yankee fans.

I am a lifelong Yankees fan starting from the mid 1950s.  My dad who had been an intensely loyal Dodgers fan, and was as mad as heck when they moved to LA, switched his loyalties to the Mets when they came along in the early 60s.  

Thus, Casey remained a hero to a great many Yankees & Mets fans both for his on field accomplishments and for his witty manners.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/29493863@N06]  Okay, I see your situation, but the way you stated it before "we are from Brooklyn and that's why" is odd because that really would not be the usual case for liking Stengel.  It would usually be the case for hating him.

I find Casey to be an interesting character in the history of the game, but in truth, he was not a very good manager by the time he took over the Yankees.  His lifetime winning record was just .508.  Frankly, anyone who could fill in a line up card could have won in those 12 seasons Casey had the Yanks.  He looked like a genius when he chose Larsen to pitch in 1956 and throw a perfect game, but there is no question in my mind that Casey lost the 1960 World Series by not going with Ford as his game one pitcher which would have allowed Ford to pitch 3 games.  That huge mistake more than anything caused Casey to be let go.  

Of course, it was also, as Casey said:  "I made the mistake of turning 70".  Once he got a team of unprotected players (the Mets), it was a case of setting a record for most losses in a season.  The manager snoozed on the bench in the late innings, the result of age and alcoholism (not much is ever mentioned about that, but Casey drank every night for many, many years).  And one of the Yankees whom I knew (I won't mention his name because one day I am going to write a story about him) told me "I saw the Old Man a number of times sleeping on the bench" during the Yankee years.  

So, looking back on it, the Yankees had the horses and Casey just happened to be in the right place at the right time.  He most certainly had hunches about situations and players, like the selection of Larsen, but, again, not starting Ford in game one, 1960 WS was just plain boneheaded.  

The Yankees were special despite the hijinks of Ford, Mantle, and Billy Martin.  Just imagine how great Mantle would have been had he not gone out drinking and carousing nearly every night with Whitey and often with Billy.  Mantle said so himself many times in his retirement and especially after his liver was shot.  Think about it, he was faster than Willie Mays getting down to first base....he was the fastest in baseball....when he batted left handed, he could run to first in 3.1 seconds.  Let me tell you, that is moving.  But, then he got hobbled up after tearing his knee up on that sprinkler head in Yankee Stadium.  Oh, there was all that baloney about him having osteo arthritis from a high school football injury.  I don't buy that because in 1953, Mantle could run with the best of them.  How many games did he play with a hangover?  Many.  Seriously, had he taken care of himself like Willie Mays did, Mantle would have hit more lifetime homeruns than Mays, but Mays was able to play 24 seasons.  Not taking anything away from Willie because like Leo Durocher always said "Willie was some kind of ballplayer.  He was the best I ever saw."  And Leo saw a lot of ball players.  So, no, I don't think Casey was that good of a manager.  And in his later years he had trouble with getting along with the young players.  The Yankees had another reason they would have won with Casey sleeping on the bench and despite his bonehead moves.  They had Yogi.  I say Yogi was responsible for many of those Yankee wins during the years he caught.  Yogi called the games.

Well, I will end here.  Casey was a character and I think much of his thinking and his speech was clouded by alcohol and then later, old age.  Let's face it, a 70 year old guy is not at the top of his game, especially if he nods off during the game.  Funny?  Yes, Stengel was as funny as Yogi, maybe even funnier at times.  Did his diatribes make sense?  Not often.  He talked in circles.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/cherriesmixednuts]  Yes, Williams and Terry hit .400, but if you look at the MLB batting avg, especially in 1930 when Terry did it, it was overall higher.  The difference is relief pitching and the rotation of five starters.  This makes it harder for batters who used to get to the starter in the late innings.  In Terry's day, there were still teams using a rotation of three pitchers, with an occasional insertion of a fourth.  When Williams hit .406 in 1941 (the last time a major leaguer has hit .400), there were no five man rotations.  Pitchers are also much better trained now in mechanics and conditioning and managers/pitching coaches carefully watch pitch counts.  No one watched pitch counts in 1941.  When you were a starter back then, you were expected to finish.  That actually was true until the early to mid seventies.  I can remember when Fergie Jenkins, one of my favorite pitchers, had 30 complete games in 1971.  Now, how many pitchers have 30 CG's in a career?   Batters definitely suffered when starters got routinely yanked by the seventh inning.  On the other hand, there has been no one with a batting eye any better than Ted Williams.  

Batters looked for ways to get an edge.  Longer, thinner handled bats that they could whip, for example.  That's legal.  But then, corked bats or bats with little super balls inside.  That's illegal.  Batters began to condition themselves better, lifting weights and using other exercise equipment.  Andre Dawson was really one of the first major stars to go heavily into weight lifting and what a six pack set of abs that guy had.  When I played in high school and college, the coaches wouldn't let us near any weights.  We were forbidden to lift weights or to go swimming because it would make us muscle bound.  Ha, now look at these players.  They all are bulked up.  And what better way to bulk up than to take performance enhancing nutrional supplements and steroids.  Then the pitchers saw what steroids did for skinny singles hitting guys like Palmeiro (that's right...look at his stats and weight with the Cubs), so some pitchers like Roger Clemens started taking steroids.  And there you have it.

I was actually trying to get to this point:  certainly expansion will always water down any sport,  however fewer really good athletes go into baseball, percentage wise, than they did in 1941.  Baseball didn't pay very much in 1941, but a good athlete could make a lot more in baseball than in pro football or pro basketball back then, and baseball was truly the American past time.  Kids everywhere played baseball.  Today, if you are a great athlete, you might not want to work toward playing baseball professionally.  The fact is, if you are Black, you are far more likely to work toward the NBA  if you have the size.  Why is this?  A couple of reasons.  One reason there are so many Black basketball stars is that playgrounds have basketball courts, not necessarily baseball  or football fields because those take up too much room.  You just need a basketball and one hoop.  The second thing is television.  Today you can watch college and NBA all season long.  Not so when I was a kid.  I lived in the Chicago area and we saw "The Big Ten game of the week" and an NBA game maybe on Saturday and Sunday.  (Soon came the Chicago Zephyrs).  Football "College game of the week" and "Big Ten game of the week".  That was it.  Third, look at colleges......not  many fans typically go to college baseball games and this has always been the case, so that when a great athlete goes to a good college, he may decide to choose basketball or football over baseball.  Some guys will play all three, but that is really rare today.  Years ago, Bob Griese played all three at Purdue.  Or guys like Dave Winfield at Minnesota.  But, today?  Maybe two sports.  But, something happened.....The NFL and the NBA started paying competitive salaries eventually.   And that, more than anything, watered down baseball.  Baseball just was not as exciting to some kids as football and basketball.  

And, of course, when Williams hit .406, there were no Blacks in baseball.  So, as Blacks entered the game in large numbers in the fifties, it really was time to expand to make room for them.  However, eventually, as I said, things did get watered down when larger salaries attracted good athletes to football and basketball.  So, it expanded and then watered down.  Now, there are fewer Black players per team than there were in the 1960s.  

I probably should take more time to write this a little more coherently, but I just wanted you to realize it wasn't all due to expansion in MLB.  And I didn't even discuss artificial turf, domed stadiums, and another HUGE factor in declining hitting which was NIGHT GAMES (although today's lighting is so much better than it was when I played).  I need to write a book on this.

And, yes, baseball IS America's game.....except that it was invented in England!!!  Now, don't let those people in Cooperstown see this.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/cherriesmixednuts]  I also think the ball was juiced a bit in 1930 and that something was done to make it less lively after that.  All sorts of records were set in 1930, especially in the American League.  

The problem is that I never saw any of those catchers you mentioned, so I can only go by what I have read over the years and what I have heard baseball people say.   So, I would pick Cochrane, then close behind would be Hartnett and Dickey.  The only clip I ever saw of Lombardi was when he snoozed.  And when you snooze, you lose.  Bresnahan was a bit earlier yet and it's hard to compare him with the others for that reason, but certainly he was the best of his era.  I saw Yogi and Campanella play....and it is really hard to choose between those two, but my guess is that either of them was better than any of those you listed.  And then came Johnny Bench.  He and I are the same age and I saw him play many times in person.  He really was a cut above any other catcher of his era including Fisk and Carter.  I was amazed at how fast Bench could run in his early years, and, of course, impressed by his arm and his huge hands and his power.  

After Bench, we have seen several fine catchers, some very good hitters.  Pudge Rodriguez was certainly a great one, and I always thought if the Cubs could had got him instead of him going to Florida, well, the Cubs would have won their first World Series in a hundred years.  I have no doubt about that.  And of course Mike Piazza.  How could you not have Piazza in the list of greatest catchers of all time?

The Pennsylvania State Memorial at Gettysburg (AKA the Pennsylvania State Monument) is the largest and most complex monument in the battlefield park. It was designed by W. Liance Cottrell (1868-1964), and erected in 1910. The final result closely resembles the design of this tabletop model, but some details (notably the swag decorations on the dome) were omitted or altered. A half-dozen individual sculptors contributed the various statues and bas reliefs that adorn the monument.

"This picturesque house was built in 1834 and at the time of the Civil War was owned by the noted statesman Thaddeus Stevens. It was on July 1, 1863 that General Robert E. Lee established his personal headquarters in this old stone house. An ideal location, it was at the center and rear of his battle lines and it was on the same road that many more of his troops were quickly approaching." – General Lee's Headquarters Museum William H. Tipton (photographer) (1850–1929) was a noted American photographer of the second half of the 19th Century, most noted for his extensive early photography of the Gettysburg Battlefield and the borough of Gettysburg, Pennsylvania. [1] [2] Robert E. Lee Headquarters, Gettsyburg – Then & Now: Significant additions and renovations have been made over the years. These views appear to be of the side and (now) rear of the house. At the time of the battle the house was probably a duplex. [3] "Lee Headquarters, Gettysburg c.1913" by William H. Tipton "General Robert E. Lee Headquarters, 2007" by Greg Peterson

Gettysburg veteran General Daniel Sickles at the Great Reunion in 1913. He died the following year at age 94. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Sickles

Interesting to caption this as "Cheering Sickles".  General Sickles himself appears to also be cheering, and every person in the photo appears to be looking at one place.

Would Sickles have been cheering himself?  Today that would seem unlikely, but I'm not sure of the etiquette for cheering in 1913.

Sickles was in his 90s at the Great Reunion, he was allowed to cheer for anything as he pleased.  ;)  And from the stories about him, I doubt etiquette was ever a major consideration in his life, at any age.

As a legislator he had pushed for the establishment of Gettysburg as a park. This Wikipedia article has a photo of the Gettysburg memorial to Meade: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Meade

An equestrian portrait of Major General George Gordon Meade looking out over the battlefield at Gettysburg where the Union army under his direction won one of its greatest battles, defeating Confederate General Robert E. Lee. He holds a pair of binoculars in his right hand and his hat in his left hand. A sword hangs from the left side of his saddle. The horse featured is Meade's favorite horse, Old Baldy. This photograph, by William H. Tipton, appears to have been made before a bronze plaque was attached to the right side of the base (although a bronze plaque on the front of the base appears to be present). Other photographs taken of veterans at the monument show the plaque in place at the time of the Great Reunion. A photograph of the model for the Meade statue was also made by Tipton. The statue was sculptured in 1895 by Henry K. Bush-Brown, (1857-1935), and the monument cost $37,500. The statue stands across the battlefield from the statue of General Robert E. Lee. – Compiled: SIRS, Gettysburg National Military Park William H. Tipton (photographer) (1850–1929) was a noted American photographer of the second half of the 19th Century, most noted for his extensive early photography of the Gettysburg Battlefield and the borough of Gettysburg, Pennsylvania. 17th Connecticut Infantry Monument, sculptured by W. H. Curtis. It was installed June 24, 1884, and dedicated July 1, 1884. The inscription on the reverse side is:
ERECTED BY THE SURVIVORS/OF THE/17TH REGIMENT, CONNECTICUT VOLUNTEERS./2ND BRIGADE, 1ST DIVISION, 11TH CORPS,/IN MEMORY OF THEIR GALLANT COMRADES/ WHO FELL HERE ON THE 1ST DAY./AND ON THIS BATTLEFIELD ON THE 2ND & 3RD DAYS OF JULY/1863/17TH CONN. VOL'S. signed
Four plaques on the monument list the names of the thirty-five men in the 17th Connecticut Infantry killed during the battle of Gettysburg. – SIRIS   Barlow's Knoll Monument – Then & Now "Summit of Barlow's Knoll, Gettysburg c.1913" from Bain/LOC   "17th Connecticut Infantry Monument (2007)" by Just Me

Wes is correct, whoever scratched the 12th is wrong, the 12th while at Gettysburg were in the 5th Army Corps which is a Maltese Cross Corps Badge, not the 2nd Corps Badge (Clover) shown on that flag. Also The only unit to be designated as the 12th PA that in Gettysburg, was the 12th PA Reserves which was also known as the 41st Pennsylvania Volunteer Infantry. The Philadelphia Brigade which was made up as the 69th, 71st, 72nd and the 106th Pennsylvania Volunteer Infantry's was in the 2nd Corps. Hopefully the LOC will do some research and fix their error.

Gen. Dan Sickles: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_Sickles

General Sickles is sitting next to his housekeeper and mistress Mrs. Wilmerding. General Sickes had one leg - thus the use of the carriage to get to the site. See comparison photograph here: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3681834943/ Close by Bloody Angle, in the background of this photograph, is where Sickles lost his leg, " Alexander's guns poured destruction upon the "bloody angle," moving forward in the desperate charge led by Barksdale against that fatal salient. Under that impetuous assault Sickles's line tell back across the stone wall. Sickles, standing with his staff at the Trostle house, was struck by a ball which broke his leg and he was carried into the house." [ ref. page 287 of Picket and His Men by La Selle Corbell Pickett (Mrs. Gen. George E. Pickett). Chapter 34 - Gettysburg 2nd day. On Google books here: books.google.com.au/books?id=N_r3ExDynecC&lpg=PA284&a... bloody angle&pg=PA287#v=onepage&q=Sickles bloody angle&f=false and in the LOC here: lccn.loc.gov/25020009

The notorious Red Velvet Swing was in one of Stanford White's apartments. According to trial testimony, White forced Evelyn Nesbit to sit naked in the swing, while he pushed it. Antonio Vachris (c1867-1944) was an Italian-American police officer on Coney Island, head of the Italian Branch of the Detective Bureau; he was famous for his role in solving a mob-related kidnapping case (in which six-year-old Michael Scimeca was held captive for 90 days in 1910). His predecessor, Lieutenant Petrosino, was murdered in Sicily in 1909, and Vachris had to go to Palermo to get "Petrosino's list," a list of hundreds of Italian criminals operating in the US. Vachris was also involved in policing adult entertainment on Coney Island. www.onewal.com/a015/f_italsquadp03.html

Possibly Mrs. Charles de Loosey Oelrichs. In 1921, according to NYT of June 30, 1921, query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F05E4DD1731EF33A... she got a divorce from Charles and custody of a 12-yr-old daughter, Marjorie. That could be the girl in the picture presumably taken some 7 years earlier. If so, the woman is the former Marjorie R. Turnbull. The wedding of daughter Marjorie to pianist and bandleader Eddy Duchin was reported in the NYT of June 6, 1935 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20D10F63C5B177A... [requires subscription] She was described as the ONLY daughter of Mrs. Marjorie Oelrichs and Charles de Loosey Oelrichs. Sadly, she died two years later of complications following childbirth. See select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30E1FFC35541B72... [again requires subscription]

Wikipedia, in its bio of Peter Duchin, describes Marjorie (in her adulthood) as a socialite of Newport, Rhode Island, and NYC. Note that in this photo her mother is holding a catalog with the words "Newport, R. I." writ large on the cover.

Marjorie's son, the society bandleader and musician Peter Duchin (Peter Oelrichs Duchin) was born on July 28, 1937. Marjorie died five days later. Peter was reared by wealthy family friends, Averell Harriman and his wife, Marie Whitney Harriman. (Harriman later was a governor of New York, but other Bain/LOC photos, contemporaneous with this one, show him as coach of the Yale rowing crew.)

New York state senator A. J. Palmer, of Ulster, N. Y. (incorrectly identified in Bain's photo), was a member of Theodore Roosevelt's Progressive Party, and a sponsor of reform legislation. In April, 1913, he introduced a bill in the N. Y. legislature to repeal public utility franchises of all types after a term of twenty-five years. In March, 1914, he was quoted in a New York Times story on the necessity of paying legislators an adequate wage, as a means of removing money from politics. This may be Mrs. Arthur Carroll, [note spelling] 64 East Seventy-seventh Street, New York City. Mrs. Annie Livingston Best, daughter of Mrs. Clermont Livingston Best, married Arthur Carroll, the elder son of General Howard Carroll and Mrs. Carroll of Carrollcliffe, Tarrytown, in September, 1910 in New York City. Arthur Carroll was a 1904 graduate of Columbia University. Annie Livingston Best had previously married Elizur Yale Smith in November, 1907, however they divorced the following June and she resumed using her maiden name. Elizur Yale Smith spent some time in jail in Kingston, NY, in 1911, after defrauding hotels with bad checks. Below is a photo of Arthur Carroll's boyhood home: "Castle on the Hudson"      by Benjamin Haas Mrs. Annie Carroll and Arthur divorced five years later, and she remarried, for the third time, W. Sackett Duell of Philadelphia, in January, 1920. —Compiled from The New York Times [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6]

See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Sulzer#Impeachment "On August 13, 1913, the New York Assembly voted to impeach Governor Sulzer, by a vote of 79 to 45. Sulzer was served with a summons to appear before the Court for the Trial of Impeachments, and Lieutenant Governor Martin H. Glynn was empowered to act in his place pending the outcome of the trial. However, Sulzer maintained that the proceedings against him were unconstitutional and refused to vacate his office.[2] Both Sulzer and Glynn claimed to be Governor. Lt.Gov. Glynn began signing documents as "Acting Governor" beginning on August 21.[3] The trial of Governor William Sulzer before the Impeachment Court began in in Albany on September 18. The court convicted Sulzer on three of the Articles of Impeachment on the afternoon of October 16, finding him guilty of filing a false report with the Secretary of State concerning his campaign contributions, committing perjury, and advising another person to commit perjury before an Assembly committee[4]. The following day, the court voted on a resolution to remove Sulzer from office. On October 17, 1913, Sulzer was removed by the same margin, a vote of 43-12, and Lt. Gov. Glynn succeeded to the governorship.[5]" The date on the negative suggests that this is the vote in the NY legislature to impeach rather than the impeachment trial.

Built for the Argentine navy. Named for Bernardino Rivadavia the first (and later, exiled) president of Argentina. Built in the USA, at the Fore River Shipbuilding Yards at Quincy, Massachusetts. Launched August 26, 1911. For awhile the Rivadavia was the largest battleship in the world: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D04E5DE163CE633A... Commissioned by the Argentine Navy in 1914, it lasted 42 years. Sold for scrap in 1956: www.maritimequest.com/warship_directory/argentina/pages/r...

I don't think the ship is under construction in this photo. It is completely outfitted with guns, lattice mast, lifeboats, etc. all of which would normally have been added after the launching of the hull,  i.e. with the ship afloat.

The ship appears to be in a drydock (Brooklyn Navy Yard?) for repairs or modifications. The riveted stern plates show signs of repeated impact and/or corrosion.

Harold "Harry" Kantner was an exhibition pilot, airplane builder, and an instructor at the Moisant Aviation School at Hempstead Plains, near Garden City, Long Island: earlyaviators.com/ekantner.htm "In the winter of 1912-13 he designed and built a new Moisant Military Scout. Known as the Kantner-Moisant Bluebird, the machine could be taken apart in four minutes and reassembled in eight. Superbly constructed, the Bluebird was successful from the start." Here Kantner is demonstrating the military plane for Navy officers. The photo negative is dated August 6, 1913. Kantner wears goggles, a sweater, and gloves. Either he has just landed, or is about to go aloft.

The Flood mansion now houses the Pacific Union Club: farm4.static.flickr.com/3205/2406911337_a4bafcbf18.jpg I think it was the only one of these buildings to survive the disaster, which happened 11 days before this paper was published.

The Tribune made a couple of caption errors on this page as well. They reversed the captions for the Flood and Huntington houses, and also gave J.C. Flood the wrong middle initial. The Flood house has been altered since the fire, with additions at the sides and the removal of the low tower above the entrance on the California Street side (seen in this photo), but is still easily recognizable. The other side of the Flood house, facing Sacramento Street, can be seen on this Tribune page, where it is misidentified as the Hopkins Art Institute. Collis P. Huntington's house, originally built by David Colton in 1872, was next door to Flood's house on the west. It was a wooden structure which, unlike Flood's substantial brownstone, was entirely consumed by the fire.

Silvius Brabo was a mythical Roman soldier who killed a giant --the names of the cities Brabant and Antwerp are said to be references to the story: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silvius_Brabo
beatiful.

this statue stands before the city hall of Antwerp. Notice Brabo holding a mutilated hand, ready to throw it away? Legends say that the city's name comes from this particular action: "hand" + "werpen (meaning to throw away)" = Antwerpen or in english, Antwerp. The hand is that of Antigoon, a giant who lived by the banks of the river Scheldt, collecting toll money from ships who sail up and down the river.

The artist who has made the scuplture - it is a fountain - was Jef Lambeaux, born in Antwerp. In the background you can see one of the old 16th century guild houses. On top there is a statue  of Saint-George (Sint-Joris) killing the dragon. This statue was also created by Jef Lambeaux and thus many years younger than the buikding itself.

@la viajera: Actually, the man dragged the chair with him that morning on the train a dozen kilometers  from Brugge, intending, when he reached Blankenberge, to rent the use of it, in ten-minute increments, to beachgoers who had tired of standing while watching the waves roll in, but who didn't want to soil their duds by squatting on the sand. 

Alas, as soon as he held up his "chair for rent" sign, the beach patrol descended on him forthwith, ordering him to desist, and threatening arrest unless he first obtained an expensive seasonal beach vendor's permit -- which he couldn't afford, and didn't want, anyway. When he began to protest, volubly, the gendarmes cautioned him: "Don't make waves!" So he sits now, stymied and disgusted, with his rolled-up rental sign in his lap -- thinking black thoughts, and hoping that a tired soul will notice him, and approach with an offer for the chair. 

At this point, the would-be entrepreneur may be willing simply to sell the chair outright, or even abandon it, and head back to Brugge in defeat.

But before he does that, it's likely that he will wander along the beach for an hour or so, looking for dropped centimes and francs to help finance his purchase of a return ticket on the chemin de fer . . . .

Everyone, 

Thanks for your comments! The caption of 'Blankenberghe, baigneurs' comes directly from the photochrom itself, and the English title is copied directly from the printed catalog produced by the Detroit Publishing Company. Sometimes these titles are not exact translations, as is the case here.  The French title does in fact mean 'Bathers' and the title given in the catalog is 'The Beach'.  At the time of this photograph, Blankenberghe was sometimes spelled in this manner, but the modern spelling seems to be Blankenberge, so we can add that spelling to the record as well.

The Theatre Royal de la Monnaie is actually the Brussels Opera House. It is allegedly the venue where the Belgian revolution started in 1830, after a rendition of Auber's nationalist opera 'La muette de Portici', eventually leading to Belgium's independence from Holland.

This is NOT Saint Bavons abbey (Sint Baafsabdij), but Saint Bavons Cathedral (Sint Baafskathedraal).  
Originally the sites didn't have anything do do with each other.  The abbey is at the (old) city border, the cathedral is in town center and used to be a parish church called St John's.
In 1539, when emperor Charles V humiliated the inhabitants of Ghent, he erected his Spaniards' Castle on the abbey grounds and forced the monks out.  Those found a new place in St John's church which became St Bavon church and later, in 1559, St Bavon cathedral.

I think the better translation is "Jacob of Artevelde": en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_van_Artevelde
@pennylrichardsca: You are right. The french text on the photo also says 'jacques' (≠ jacob).

pennylrichardsca and it is aai: Thanks for your comments! The title of John of Artevelde was taken from the English language catalog published by the Detroit Publishing Company, and I agree that the translation they provided seems less than accurate. Apparently, the gentleman who inspired this statue was best known as Jacob van Artevelde (c.1290-1345), but was sometimes referred to as Jacques van Artevelde as well. (An example being this 1942 book on Artevelde.) Since the caption on the photochrom itself is in French, the use of Jacques there seems to fit. We will expand this description to better reflect the various forms of Artevelde's name when we update.

This is absolutely certain the statue of Jacob van Artevelde (Jacob = Jacques = James).    John van Artevelde was a city sheriff in the beginning of the 14th century (John = Jan = Jean).  John may or may not have been a relative of Jacob, some sources claim that Jacob is Johns' son.  But the origins of Jacob remain very unclear.
Jacob played an important role in negotiations between Flanders and England about wool trade, and hence made him an enemy of France.
He was murdered on 24th July 1345, for until now unknown reasons.
The statue was erected in 1863.

The building at the right hand side in the picture, het Toreken, was the guild house of the tanners, now housing a poetry centre.

Saint Jacobs church is behind the houses in the background, and has no link with Jacob Van Artevelde.

James "Death Valley Jim" Scott (April 23, 1888 - April 7, 1957) was a pitcher for the Chicago White Sox (1909-1917). He born in Deadwood, South Dakota. He helped the White Sox win the 1917 World Series. He finished 14th in voting for the 1913 American League MVP for leading the league in Games Started (38) and having a 20-20 Win-Loss record, 48 Games, 25 Complete Games, 4 Shutouts, 6 Games Finished, 1 Save, 312 ⅓ Innings Pitched, 252 Hits Allowed, 96 Runs Allowed, 66 Earned Runs Allowed, 2 Home Runs Allowed, 86 Walks, 158 Strikeouts, 9 Hit Batsmen, 3 Wild Pitches, 1,203 Batters Faced and a 1.90 ERA. He also led the AL in Games Finished (17) in 1910 and Shutouts (7) in 1915. He ranks 17th on the MLB All-Time ERA List (2.30), 96th on the All-Time WHIP List (1.18) and 54th on the All-Time Hits Allowed/9IP List (7.73). In 9 seasons he had a 107-113 Win-Loss record, 317 Games (226 Started), 123 Complete Games, 26 Shutouts, 63 Games Finished, 9 Saves, 1,892 Innings Pitched, 1,624 Hits Allowed, 686 Runs Allowed, 483 Earned Runs Allowed, 21 Home Runs Allowed, 609 Walks, 945 Strikeouts, 53 Hit Batsmen, 33 Wild Pitches, 7,468 Batters Faced, 3 Balks and a 2.30 ERA. An alumnus of Nebraska Wesleyan University, he died in Jacumba, California at the age of 68. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Scott_(pitcher)

That was a nice catcher's mitt for 1912.  Plenty of padding.  The catcher had to catch two handed as it was still quite a few years before the mitt was hinged and had a web which allowed for one handed catching.  Most catchers had numerous broken fingers over their careers.  Catcher's gear was jokingly referred to as "tools of ignorance," but the catcher often was the most knowledgeable guy on the team, knowing how to handle pitchers and how opposing hitters batted and ran on the bases.  Many baseball managers and coaches were at one time catchers, including Al Lopez, Ray Shalk, Branch Rickey, Yogi Berra, Connie Mack, Roger Bresnahan, Mike Scioscia, Joe Torre, Joe Girardi, Bill Dickey, Ned Yost, Mickey Cochrane, Del Crandall,and Bob Brenly,
And don't forget the insightful in-game commentary from the likes of Joe Garagiola and Tim McCarver.
Add to that list of catcher/managers Eric Wedge of the Seattle Mariners.

August 1913 saw the reformation of the taxi hacking industry in NYC. A new public hacking ordinance was introduced to abolish private cab stands and reduce taxi fare rates. The new ordinance went into effect at 0000hours on August 1, 1913. A new style of taximeter was also required adjusted to register the new rates of fare. ( ref. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9900E2DC163DE633A... & As you could imagine, the taxi industry did not take kindly to the reforms. (ref. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A0CE5DC163DE633A... ) According to an article in the NYT of August 3, 1913, August 2 was a big day for vehicle inspections: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9403EFDD113BE633A...
Note smooth tread tires, starting crank, no headlights, no bumper. Typical automobile for the period.

This would be Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany and King Victor Emmanuel III of Italy. The ship appears to the Hohenzollern, the official yacht of Kaiser Wilhelm II ( ref. comparison diagram: www.german-navy.de/hochseeflotte/ships/misc/hohenzollern/... and comparison postcard view: www.imageenvision.com/stock_photo/details/0003-0707-0120-... ) This could be the meeting with King Victor in Venice on March 25, 1912 : query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F07EED9133AE633A...

The King and Queen of Italy were to meet (in the near future) the Kaiser at Kiel, in Germany according to this July 2, 1913 article in the NYT: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9904E3DE1730E233A... Here is a July 20, 1913 NYT report of the talks held at Kiel between the Kaiser and the King of Italy: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B06E6DE113CE6... Margaret Frances Andrews was the only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Andrews of Newport, RI.  In 1911, she was rumored to be engaged to William Vincent Astor, who would later die on the Titanic.  

In 1915, she married Morgan Belmont (1892-1953), at her parents' home, Rockery Hall; as reported in the New York Times, "The occasion marked the union of members of two of the oldest families in Newport's social history, and a representative gathering of the Summer colony was present.  Owing to the bride's family being in mourning, the number of guests was limited to 150."

The christening of her daughter, Margaret Andrews Morgan Belmont, was reported in August 1917.

Consolidated Gas Company (now Consolidated Edison) headquarters, at 15th and Irving. Photograph is from construction between 1911-1914. They're installing girders after the surrounding buildings were completed, to raise this structure another six floors. Probably 1913? "By this time, however, the firm had decided that a 12-story building would be inadequate. More land was purchased to the east, and Hardenbergh was requested to design and 18-story building for the entire site. There was no problem in constructing the structures for the east and west sides of the lot, but the original 12-story central section did not have a structural system that could support extra floors. The solution was to build the end wings and then construct girders between them and suspend the additional stories."
The date is visible along the top right side in reverse: 8/4/13 (Aug.4, 1913)

Binghamton NY was the site of a terrible fire in July 1913, when the Binghamton Clothing Factory fire claimed 31 lives. Twenty-one bodies were left unidentified, and after a memorial service at the Stone Opera House (presided over by a Rabbi, a Catholic priest, and a Lutheran pastor, just to cover all the likely bases), they were buried in the Spring Forest Cemetery. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1913_Binghamton_Factory_Fire Just a few weeks ago, Binghamton dedicated a plaque to the workers lost in this fire: www.wbng.com/news/local/51419212.html
Photo taken at burial service for 21 unidentified victims, July 27, 1913.

Lincolndale Agricultural School for Boys was a Catholic charity run under a Brother Barnabas, opened in 1912 for selected orphans to be trained for agricultural and industrial work. On 9 March 1913, Brother Barnabas was quoted in the New York Times--at a conference on vocational schools, Brother Barnabas spoke against profit-making in such institutions, saying
"It is a step backwards when we take those who are not able to support themselves and make them support us. Surely if they are able to support others they are able to go out into the community where they can work for themselves. The minute that a boy is self-supporting his place is in society and in a good home."
I started an entry in Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincolndale_Agricultural_School

The open-sided street cars were used only in summer. The benches on these cars were configured in transverse rows, unlike those of the winter cars, which lined the sides while facing a central aisle. Here there was no aisle. Instead, the passenger swung herself up from a running board, after making a quick check of the benches, to be sure of seating space on the one chosen. The conductor collected fares from the running board, while the car was in motion. (A doubly awkward task when rain was pouring down.)

A Naval Militia in the USA is usually part of the State defence organization. Here's info on New York's one: www.dmna.state.ny.us/nynm/naval.php
The dates on both the negative and the sticker begin with 4 and end with 7 or 17, indicating April 1917. The original day of the month appears to have been changed, possibly corrected.
So here's another instance of Bain's reuse of a 1913 military photo after Wilson's (and Congress's) declaration of war against Germany (April 6, 1917).

From Wikipedia: Lattice masts, or cage masts, are a type of observation mast common on major warships in the early 20th century. They were used most prominently on American dreadnought battleships and armored cruisers of the World War I era. Their purpose was to make the observation posts mounted on the masts and used to direct the fire of the warships' guns less vulnerable to shells from enemy ships.
