Battleship USS Alabama (BB-08).  Used for an extensive period as a training vessel for Naval Militias:

" Alabama was placed in reserve at New York on 3 November 1908. Though she remained inactive at New York, the battleship was not decommissioned until 17 August 1909. The warship underwent an extensive overhaul that lasted until the early part of 1 912. On 17 April 1912, she was placed in commission, second reserve, at New York, Comdr. Charles F. Preston in command. At that point, she became an element of the newly established Atlantic Reserve Fleet. According to that concept, the Navy organize d a unit that comprised nine of the older battleships as well as Brooklyn (Armored Cruiser No. 3), Columbia (Cruiser No. 12), and Minneapolis (Cruiser No. 13) for the purpose of keeping those ships constantly read for active servi ce using the fiscal expedient of severely reduced complements that could be filled out rapidly by naval militiamen and volunteers in an emergency. The unit as a whole possessed enough officers and men to take two or three of the ships to sea on a rota ting basis to test their material readiness and to exercise the sailors at drill. 

Alabama was placed in full commission on 25 July 1912 and operated with the Atlantic Fleet off the New England coast through the summer. She was returned to reserve status-in commission, first reserve-at New York on 10 September 1912. Late in t he spring of 1913, the Navy added a new dimension to the concept of the Atlantic Reserve Fleet by having the warships of that unit embark detachments of the various state naval militias for training afloat in a manner similar in many respects to the c ontemporary Navy's selected reserve program. During the summer of 1913, Alabama cruised along the east coast and made two round-trip voyages to Bermuda to train naval militiamen from Maryland, the District of Columbia, New York, Rhode Island, M aine, North Carolina, and Indiana. She ended her last training cruise of the year at Philadelphia on 2 September. The battleship was placed in ordinary on 31 October 1913 and in reserve on 1 July 1914"

@technogeo --- that was the day after the U. S. declared war on Germany, and entered World War I (April 6, 1917). So the sticker must have been placed deliberately to cover the earlier scratched-on date, and allow reuse of the 1913 photo to publicize war preparedness.

A passenger train is running from left to right in the background. The steam locomotive is no. 1528, possibly of the New York Central RR. It looks like a switcher (0-6-0). The gondola cars on the right are marked NYC & HR (New York Central and Hudson River?)

On closer inspection: The locomotive has two wheels on its leading truck, making it a 2-6-0 or Mogul type engine. There are passengers on board, so the engine isn't just shunting cars. 

There is another locomotive just behind, on the adjacent track, heading from right to left. Only the top of the cab is visible, above the tender of the train in the foreground. It is pulling five gondola cars that might be filled with material for the construction site behind the sailors.

I started an entry in Wikipedia: Alfred Holland Smith (1863-1924) was president of the New York Central Railroad. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Holland_Smith

Smith was in the news (per Bain) on July 30, 1913, when he was still Senior Vice President of the NYCRR. He did not become president until December 31 of that year.

In 1913, Smith was appointed a member of the railroad arbitration board, designed to head off strikes. Other members of the board, including Seth Low, appear in several Bain photos posted earlier on the LOC photostream.

James Mark Sullivan (1873-19201935), cousin of Tammany Hall's Tim Sullivan, was an Irish-born, Yale-educated lawyer and an American diplomat (briefly the minister to Santo Domingo) who (after leaving the State Department's employ) was arrested in Dublin in 1916 for aiding the Irish rebellion. See Maryanne Felter and Daniel Schultz, "James Mark Sullivan and the Film Company of Ireland," New Hibernia Review 8(2)(2004): 24-40, for a recent scholarly exploration of Sullivan's business interests.
I started a Wikipedia entry for him: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Mark_Sullivan He died in 1935, not in 1920 as listed above. The State Department lists 1933, but his obit appears in 1935.

Ottoman Cyprus was rented to the British in 1878 in exchange for Britain's favours at the Congress of Berlin.

Egypt, which had previously been occupied by the forces of Napoleon I of France in 1798 but recovered in 1801 by a joint Ottoman-British force, was occupied in 1882 by British forces on the pretext of bringing order; though Egypt and Sudan remained as Ottoman provinces (de jure) until 1914, when the Ottoman Empire joined the Central Powers of World War I, and Britain officially annexed these two provinces and Cyprus as a response. Other Ottoman provinces in North Africa were lost between 1830 and 1912, starting from Algeria (occupied by France in 1830), Tunisia (occupied by France in 1881) and Libya (occupied by Italy in 1912.)

The Armenians, who were granted their own constitution and national assembly with the Tanzimat reforms, began pressing the Ottoman government for greater autonomy after the Russo-Turkish War of 1877-1878 and the Congress of Berlin in 1878. A number of Armenian uprisings took place in the cities of Anatolia, and Armenian militants seized the Ottoman Bank headquarters in Constantinople.Sultan Abdul Hamid II responded to these uprisings and attacks by establishing the Hamidiye regiments in eastern Anatolia, formed mostly of irregular cavalry units of recruited Kurds. In 1894–96 more than 50,000 Armenians were killed during the Hamidian massacres.

Samuel Seabury was a New York State judge in the 1910s, and in 1916 resigned to seek the governorship. In the early thirties he lead the Seabury Commission that investigated and cleaned up corruption in New York City courts.

In 1913, Seabury was the unsuccessful Progressive Party candidate for an Associate Justice vacancy on the New York State Court of Appeals. The photo bears Bain's date of August 7, 1913 -- perhaps the time when Seabury announced his candidacy.

Adolph Olson "A.O." Eberhart, (1870-1944). Born in Sweden, "A.O." came to Minnesota in 1881. He became Governor of Minnesota when John Albert Johnson died in office, serving from 1909 to 1915 . He ran and lost in the Republican primary for the United States Senate in 1916. –Minnesota Legislative Reference Library While guessing who the photographer was from the cropped photo-credit is a bit like playing (the US game show) Wheel of Fortune, my hit is it was Alfred Miller of Minneapolis/Saint Paul – in part because of this photograph of Governor Eberhart taken by Alfred Miller in 1913.

Under Governor Eberhart, in 1913 Minnesota established the first economy and efficiency commission of any political jurisdiction anywhere. Also in 1913, as part of a reform wave, Minnesota made its legislature nonpartisan.

Pixel Wrangler: Thank you for the additional information on Gov. Eberhart. We will expand the record when we update. This is one of those photographs found in the George Grantham Bain Collection (described here) where the folks at Bain News Service acquired the work of another photographer to distribute, and in the process of copying it, cut off part of the original credit. Upon viewing the largest digital file over in the Prints and Photographs Online Catalog (available here), it looks like it's Alfred W- of Minneapolis, so the mystery may continue!

August, 1913: Before the Suffragette Caravan left New York for Boston, pulled by a balky horse that the ladies had named "Asquith," (after the British prime minister, who also had been balky in offering support to the cause of woman suffrage) the participants (three British suffragettes and Ida Craft, an American Salvation Army colonel, with tambourine) released several homing pigeons, whose flight back to Boston was supposed to precede and herald their own arrival in that city. Here is a contemporary newspaper clipping about the event: www.elizabethfreeman.org/PDF/suffrage/bostonPigeons_big.pdf Sign on wagon front says: BUY - ONLY - 5c WEEKLY THE - WOMEN'S - JOURNAL ALL - THE - LATEST - NEWS ON WOMAN'S - SUFFRAGE ______________________ Signs on side of wagon front: VOTES FOR WOMEN THE WOMAN'S JOURNAL -------- GIVE - WOMEN THE VOTE - QUICK

Admiral Frank Friday Fletcher (November 23, 1855–November 28, 1928) was an American naval officer of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. In connection with these operations, he was at times on shore and under fire. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Friday_Fletcher

This is Jesse Grant, a mining engineer and youngest son of U. S. President Ulysses S. Grant. In the 1912 election he broke with the Republican Party of his father and was strong in support of the Democratic Party and its candidate, Woodrow Wilson. He was in the news on this particular day, July 24, 1913, because on the preceding day, in Goldfield, Nevada, he had filed for divorce from his wife Elizabeth, then living in California, whom he had not seen for over two years. Divorce was unusual in 1913, and of course a scandal when it touched the lives of the mighty or their heirs. Incidentally, the suit for divorce was denied.

August, 1913: Before the Suffragette Caravan left New York for Boston, pulled by a balky horse that the ladies had named "Asquith," (after the British prime minister, also balky in support of woman suffrage) the participants (three British suffragettes and an American Salvation Army colonel -- with tambourine) released several Boston homing pigeons, whose flight home was supposed to precede their own arrival in that city. The sandstone arch at bottom right looks like Delicate Arch in Arches National Park. See www.utah.com/art/photos/moab/gallery-delicatearch.jpg More at www.utah.com/nationalparks/arches/delicate-arch.htm www.archive.org/stream/nationalparkpict00deparich#page/n1... a book listing pictures from national parks that was received by the University of California in 1914 describes the Edwin, Augusta, and Caroline natural bridges and locates them in "Natural Bridges National Monument, Utah." From www.americansouthwest.net/utah/natural_bridges/national_m... "the three bridges, currently known as Sipapu, Kachina and Owachomo after their original names were changed to reflect the Hopi Indian history of the area."

More on the namingof the natural bridges, from www.visit4corners.com/Utah/Parks-Sights/Bridges/Bridges.htm Naming the Bridges Several names have been applied to the bridges. First named "President," "Senator" and "Congressman" by Cass Hite, the bridges were renamed "Augusta," "Caroline" and "Edwin" by later explorer groups. As the park was expanded to protect nearby Puebloan structures, the General Land Office assigned the Hopi names "Sipapu," "Kachina" and "Owachomo" in 1909. Sipapu means "the place of emergence," an entryway by which the Hopi believe their ancestors came into this world. Kachina is named for rock art on the bridge that resembles symbols commonly used on kachina dolls. Owachomo means "rock mound," a feature atop the bridge's east abutment.

Carmania belonged to the Cunard Line.  She entered service in 1905 along with her near-identical sister Caronia.  Of the two, Carmania was equipped with turbines whilst Caronia had the standard engines, an experiment designed to determine how the upcoming Lusitania and Mauretania would be engined.  Carmania was the faster ship.  The experiment was a success and the new liners received turbine engines.  Carmania served as an Armed Merchant Cruiser in World War 1 and has the distinction of being the only liner to engage and sink another liner named Cap Trafalgar in a battle of Trinidad in September 1914.
My family came to America arriving in Boston in 1923 on the Carmania.

An ad was placed in the New York Herald in May of 1906 offering investors a chance to get in on this investment in the Globe Tower that was projected to cost $1,500,000 and was expected to pay up to 100% interest annually. Not unlike current times, investors flocked to the project and plunked down their hard earned dollars with visions of a fortune in their future. There was a ceremony for laying the cornerstone on May 26, 1906 with the usual pomp and circumstance. By the end of the year, the foundations were still not laid and investors began to get nervous. So on February 17, 1907 another ceremony was held and the first piece of steel was installed. Promises were made to be 50% complete by May 15th and 100% complete by the end of 1908. By 1908 the fraud was evident, the dream was dashed and there was no government bailout. BUT, we did get some very nice postcards. www.americanchronicle.com/articles/view/79558

Asbury hot dogs were in the news in 1913:

The New York Times June 24, 1913 
_________________________________


ASBURY BANS "HOT DOGS." 

____________ 

Question of Sunday Sale to go Before Courts for Settlement. 
____________ 

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 23.--- Shall Asbury Park be without "hot dogs" of a Sunday? The question will soon be settled in the courts, for Murphy & Krug, who conduct an eating place on the boardwalk, have started a civil suit against Mayor Reginald S. Bennett for preventing the open sale of their speciality on the first day of the week.

Krug & Murphy say that some weeks ago they found there was a demand on the part of promenaders and bathers for frankfurter sausages on rolls, such as one sees at Coney Island. The caterers at once placed a big supply on exhibition, surmounted by a sign calling attention to the digestibility of their offerings.

When Mayor Bennett heard about it, it is said that he called an emergency meeting of his cabinet, at which it was decided that such sales on Sundays would not add to the dignity of the beach. Murphy & Krug received information to that effect.

Permission, however, was given to continue the sale of the sausages in the rear of the restraunt on Sundays. Murphy & Krug defied the Mayor, and yesterday morning the frankfurters publicly were offered for sale. A rush of customers was quickly followed by a rush of police, and for the rest of the day a policeman stood on fixed post in front of the restraunt by order of the Mayor, turning customers away. The law suit is the consequence, the plaintiffs saying that Mayor Bennett has neither legal nor a moral right to interfere.

The photographer was standing in Asbury Park, but the photo is actually of the North End Hotel and Pavilion in neighboring Ocean Grove. The Hotel was demolished years ago, but the pavilion on the left is still in operation.

@ Harry Polny:  The presence of horses need not imply that this was a cavalry unit.  The Field Artillery used vast numbers of horses in this era to pull cannon, ammunition limbers and all the other paraphernalia needed to support the guns.  Indeed, any regimental or higher headquarters would have had a number of horses to the transport of commanders and staff officers.

Marthe Chenal (1881 – 28 January 1947) was a French operatic soprano who had an active singing career between 1905 and 1923. Although she made a number of appearances with opera companies throughout the French provinces and on the international stage, her career was mainly centered at the Palais Garnier and the Opéra-Comique in Paris. She particularly excelled in the works of Jules Massenet and was an exponent of the works of Camille Erlanger. Chenal was admired not only for her excellent singing but also her dramatic prowess, with a number of critics comparing her to the great French dramatic actress Sarah Bernhardt. A remarkably attractive woman, Chenal was dubbed by the international press as "the most beautiful woman in Paris". She was noted for her rendition of La Marseillaise. Her voice is preserved on a number of recordings made with Pathé Records in 1915 en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marthe_Chenal

It's xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx of Sing Sing prison: It's Warden James M. Clancy of Sing Sing prison: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9807E3DF143EE733A...

No "e" in Clancy. 

James Clancy was appointed warden of Sing Sing in July, 1913, at about the time that an arson fire damaged several of the prison workshop buildings. Official reports had slammed inhuman conditions at the prison -- blamed on the cramped and antiquated facilities (built in 1821), and not on the warden or his minions. Clancy, who had no prison experience, was overwhelmed, and tried to resign in October, 1913, then again in April, 1914, after having no luck in persuading the legislature to appropriate funds to ameliorate conditions.

Norway, which had newly gained its independence from Sweden, crowned this jolly couple king and queen in 1906. (The royal family came to Norway from Denmark, but before her marriage to Haakon in 1896, Maud had been Princess of Wales.)

Norway was in the news in 1913 for granting full suffrage to women.

Haakon VII (Prince Carl of Denmark and Iceland, born Christian Frederik Carl Georg Valdemar Axel) (3 August 1872 at Charlottenlund Palace – 21 September 1957 in Oslo), known as Prince Carl of Denmark until 1905, was the first king of Norway after the 1905 dissolution of the personal union with Sweden. He was a member of the House of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg. As one of the few elected monarchs, Haakon quickly won the respect and affection of his people and played a pivotal role in uniting the Norwegian nation in its resistance to the attack and five-year-long Nazi occupation during World War II. In Norway, Haakon is regarded as one of the greatest Norwegians of the twentieth century and is particularly revered for his courage during the German invasion - when threatening abdication if the government cooperated with the invading Germans - and his leadership and preservation of Norwegian unity during the Nazi occupation. He died at the age of 85 in 1957, after having reigned for nearly 52 years. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haakon_VII_of_Norway

In 1913, the California legislature overrode objections of President Woodrow Wilson and the government of Japan, and enacted the racist Alien Land Law, which restricted ownership of land in California by Japanese immigrants. (Japanese already were ineligible for naturalization as U. S. citizens.) Ebara was a member of a 1913 Japanese delegation to the U. S. to protest the California act. Mona, I have trouble reading the dates, but once someone like Wystan has found a date on the plate negative, then we can do a search of the New York Times to find out more. If we go to the advanced search funtion of the NYT archive, and knowing that Tim Sullivan is the most well known person in this group, let's search of "Tim Sullivan" from July 1, 1913 to July 31, 1913: query.nytimes.com/search/query?frow=0&n=10&srcht=... Then scan the headlines and dates together, and we see a headline "Big Tim Sullivan Returns Imroved; Presence of Politician on Imperator a Secret Until Ship Reaches ..." and dated July 17, 1913. Usually, we look for an article dated the day after the date on the negative, but there is no article for July 18, 1913 in this search. So let's try the one on July 17, 1913: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9904E5DD163DE633A... and here: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9904E... Neither of these articels exactly correlates with the date on the plate identified by Wystan, but we get a good idea of the fact that a sick Big Tim is back in town.

At the time she was the largest passenger liner in service, and cruised at 23 knots. This would have been the height of trans-Atlantic luxury at the time. She was equipped with a swimming pool, and so much marble in the upper deck cabins that she was top heavy and suffered from stability problems. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Imperator

I don't think it's the 3rd HMS Conway (the one that was wrecked being towed for a refit in 1953) as from the photos I can find of it under tow (and earlier) it had two rows of gunports, each with a distinctive white stripe whilst the one in the photo has only a single row and stripe. Also she was only stationed in the Mersey until 1941, being moved to the Menai Straights to avoid the blitz. The ship in the photo looks like she's the same class as the second HMS Conway, originally HMS Winchester, a 51 gun frigate, but she swapped the name with HMS Nile in 1876. There's a nice photo of her at Saltash in her final incarnation as the reform ship Mount Edgcumbe. So my guess is that she's a Royal Navy frigate, but we're unlikely to ever know the name. :-(

Of course no sooner do I write that than I find by a Google image search that the ship was the former HMS Clio, built in 1858 as a 22 gun corvette and lent by the navy as the Industrial Training Ship Clio. She was stationed in the Menai Straights from 1877 (moved there from the River Dee) until she was scrapped in 1920. There's a nice photo of her at anchor at the bottom of the Ysgol Llandegfan page on Llandegfan village (ysgol is Welsh for school). So, this photo must be sometime between 1877 and 1920.
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/94482242@N00/] a bit late to tell you now. But the ship is the ‘HMS Clio’, a 22 gun Corvette used as a training ship around the turn of the 20th century.

Are these scans of the postcars retouched in any way? the qualiy seems superb but the colours smack of having been worked on in Photoshop - they seem to be very vivid for 100 year old prints. Can you clarify please.

The scene above takes in one of my favourite bike ride routes when I was still living in the UK (I'm local born from nearby Ynys Môn), there are more trees nowadays but it is remarkibly similar outlook.

Can I also ask Vagabond Jewelry why she posted the link to the photochrom wiki on all these images (just curious)?

The photochrom wiki explains the colours that you're asking about - these were taken with black and white film and the photochrom process is, more or less, a way to automate hand colouring. Hence the very vivid colors

OK, Thanks for explaining. So you are saying these postcards are photographic prints with multiple litho spot-colour tints applied afterwards? It must have been murder inking, hefting, registeringa and printing multiple stones, probably hundreds, possibly thousands of times for each run of images (I mean - lots were printed to make money no?...) 

What I can't understand is how the images are so vivid after nearly 120 years. They must have been stored in an light/air-tight environment for the last 90 years to look so good, either that, or they have been tweaked for saturation after scanning.

It's great that these prints are being digitised, though it's odd to see the Library of Congeress doing it when the images are of a little country which is part of a small island on the other side of the Atlantic (speaking as a Welshman...).

Based on the time they were printed, one would assume oil based inks- which will keep their colour for a very very long time- just as long as oil based paints, in fact. Turner's paintings surely have not faded. 

I agree- it is amazing the variety of images the Library of Congress has! I think that, more or less, they keep everything they are given, and the link they provided gives some insight on where this particular trove came from. It's wonderful stuff, isn't it?

The Chain Bridge Hotel is uniquely situated on a narrow strip of land between the dramatic fast-flowing waters of the River Dee on one side, and the serene Llangollen Canal on the other. Access to the hotel is via a long, narrow drive. Berwyn Station with its famous steam trains is located across the river from the hotel. The chain bridge, from which the hotel takes its name, was originally constructed in 1814 by Exuperious Pickering, a local owner of coal mines and lime kilns, to enable him to take his coal across the river for delivery to Corwen and Bala while avoiding three toll fees over the Llangollen Town Bridge. The original bridge hung from a network of handmade chains, and became the most famous and unique bridge on the river. It was refurbished and strengthened in 1870, rebuilt in 1876, and rebuilt again in 1929. The bridge has been closed due to safety reasons for the past 30 years, however a recent grant from the Heritage Lottery Fund will allow a thorough evaluation of the bridge, and determine the cost to restore it (if further funding is available). The original Chain Bridge Inn was most likely built around the same time as the bridge (c.1814). In the 1870s the Inn was rebuilt and enlarged in the black and white style that can be seen today. The Tudor Bar is situated in the main, 1870, building, and has black and white beams, with an Inglenook fireplace. William Watson (1873-1961), the Liverpool-born champion cylist, racing driver and motoring pioneer, was also interested in hotels, and briefly owned the Chain Bridge Hotel around 1960. Seamus O'Keeffe and his wife Elizabeth, bought the hotel in 2012 for £500,000, and have pledged to fully restore the hotel by the Bicentennial of the hotel in 2014. —Compiled [1 [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] [8] [9]   Chain Bridge Hotel – Then and Now (100+ years later) At some point a major three-story addition was made, significantly increasing the length of the hotel along the river-front. The first floor is an enlarged dining area, with two floors of rooms above. The hotel currently has 36 rooms.   "Chainbridge Hotel (2010)" by Jeff McDonald    "Chain Bridge Hotel (c.1890)"       by LOC

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Prince Sehzade Yusuf Izzeddin Effendi (10 October 1857 - 1 February 1916) was the Son of Sultan Abdul Aziz and the Crown Prince of the Ottoman Empire from 1909 until his death. Prince Yusuf lived in obscurity from the time of his father's death in 1876 until the dethronement of his cousin, Sultan Abdul Hamid II in 1909. Under the Turkish constitution, Yusuf, the oldest Ottoman prince, became heir to his cousin, Mehmed V. Considered a modernizer and reformer, he apparently committed suicide on 1 February 1916. It was suspected at the time that he might have been murdered at the connivance of the powerful minister of war, Enver Pasha, with whom he had clashed.


Mehmed VI Wahid ed-din (Ottoman Turkish: محمد سادس Meḥmed-i sâdis, Turkish: Mehmed Vahideddin or Mehmet Vahdettin) (14 January/2 February 1861  – 15/16 May 1926) was the 36th and last Sultan of the Ottoman Empire, reigning from 1918 to 1922. The brother of Mehmed V, he succeeded to the throne as the eldest male member of the House of Osman after the 1916 suicide ? of Abdülaziz's son Yusuf Izzettin, the heir to the throne. He was girded with the Sword of Osman on July 4, 1918, as the thirty-sixth padishah. His mother was Gülüstü, (1831 - May 1861), originally named Henriet, a Circassian.His Fullsister was Mediha Sultana (30 JUL 1856, Bechiktache, 7 JAN 1928, Mentone).

The trucks look like they were made by the White Motor Company of Cleveland.
technogeo:  Could you give us a little more information on why you think these trucks were made by the White Motor Company? It would be great to identify them!

The contoured shape of the radiator shell and hood suggest these are White trucks. The shape is almost identical on White steam cars, made from 1900 to 1910. (White steamers were the official cars of President Taft and his staff). The hexagonal bronze hub caps are also typical of White cars. The name "White," engraved in script, is just visible on the front wheel's hub cap in the high-res version.

The White Motor Company switched production to internal combustion cars and trucks in 1910.

Looking at an enhanced version of this, the people are watching a scoreboard being updated with the plays shown on a baseball diamond sign. The game is between the Brooklyn Superbas (Dodgers) and the New York Giants. There is no score in the bottom of the third inning. It should be possible to date this picture by box scores. Something about the scoreboard they are watching: "The Evening Sun's electric scoreboard on which a ball is moved automatically about the diamond enables thousand of fans to follow every detail of the day's game." Pathe's Weekly, July 24, 1913 books.google.com/books?id=3Ew_AAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA558&... Before the advent of radio doomed them, these electric scoreboards attracted huge crowds in New York and elsewhere.

A date of 1912 was set by the Pictorial History Committee, Society for American Baseball Research, according to the notes above. However, with some enhancement the teams' rosters are legible, and the lineups match a game played at the Polo Grounds between the teams on June 24, 1913. The negative has a 1913 date written on it, though that is not dispositive. Casey Stengel, on the scoreboard lineup, did not make his major league debut until September 17, 1912, and the Giants did not play the Dodgers at the Polo Grounds after September 9 that season. Placement of the Brooklyn lineup on the left and the Giants on the right typically meant the game was played at the Giants' field. This is therefore the game of June 24, 1913 which Eddie Stack started for Brooklyn. He only lasted 3 innings, so this picture was taken early in the game. Stack was traded to the Cubs on August 5, 1913. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60914FF3E5B1373... www.baseball-reference.com/teams/BRO/1912-schedule-scores... www.baseball-reference.com/teams/BRO/1913-schedule-scores... www.baseball-reference.com/players/s/stacked01.shtml www.baseball-reference.com/players/s/stengca01.shtml

Tom Needham (April 17, 1879 - December 13, 1926) was a professional baseball player from 1904 to 1914. His first four years, were with the Boston Beaneaters (Later the Boston Braves). Needham hit poorly, Hitting below .200 twice. After a brief appearance with the New York Giants in 1908, Needham played his last 6 years with the Chicago Cubs. Still, Needham hit badly, hitting over .200 just once. Despite hitting under .200 8 of his 11 seasons, Needham's career average was .209, due to his first season average of .260. May 8, 1908, Friday

Page 14, 896 words

" Andy Carnegie," so the programme said, gave a dinner at the Waldorf last night, at which the invited guests failed to show up. Their places were filled by "Joe Cannon," "Senator Foraker," "Gov. Johnson," "Vice President Fairbanks," "William R. Hearst," "Gov. Hughes," "William Jennings Bryan," "Secretary Taft," and "President [Theodore] Roosevelt," the same being the result of the efforts of "Booker Washington," whom, as the waiter, "Mr. Carnegie" dispatched into the street to obtain guests. 

Source:http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D0DE2DA173EE033A2575BC0A9639C946997D6CF

Presumably this photo dates from 1913, as do all the others in this photostream sequence of the Bain/LOC negatives. Andrew Carnegie and William Jennings Bryan had been friends since Bryan's presidential campaign of 1896, when Carnegie supported his candidacy. In 1913, Bryan was the newly-appointed Secretary of State in Woodrow Wilson's cabinet. This photo may document a meeting of the board of directors of Carnegie's pet project of the time, the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. If so, many of the less familiar faces there are politicians of high rank, university presidents, etc.

Definitely NOT "Taft and Wilson".

This photo is depicted in The Washington herald., May 13, 1913, Page 4, "DISTINGUISHED PEACE LEADERS VISITING WASHINGTON". The persons in the foreground are (besides of Carnegie and Bryan) Philip Stanhope, 1st Baron Weardale and Sir George Houstoun Reid.
B-59:  Thanks for your sleuthing here.  We will include the names of the additional persons pictured in the Washington Herald next time we update the description.

After some research here, I am fairly certain this photograph relates to the celebration of 100 years of peace between the United States and the British Empire after the 1814 Treaty of Ghent ending the War of 1812. A meeting took place in New York City with delegates from May 5-9, 1913, and then it appears the delegates went to Washington D.C. Meetings took place in May of 1913 with various delegates from the United States, Great Britain, Canada, Newfoundland, Australia and New Zealand. Sir Byron Edmund Walker, a delegate from Canada can be seen behind Carnegie.(en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byron_Edmund_Walker) Sources: Chicago Commerce (books.google.ca/books?id=VQerfUMv9v0C&newbks=0&dq...) International Conference in New York on May 5-9 discussed in Canadian Parliament (www.google.ca/books/edition/Official_Report_of_Debates_Ho...) The Globe (1844-1936); Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 13 May 1913: 15. (Proquest 1351240809) discusses monuments to be erected in Great Britain and the United States. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglo-American_Peace_Centenary en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Peace_Centenary_Committee This photo and others of the same moment appears a few times. Evening star. [volume] (Washington, D.C.), 12 May 1913. Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress. (chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1913-05-12/ed-...) The Washington herald. [volume] (Washington, D.C.), 13 May 1913. Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress. (chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1913-05-13/ed-...) The Washington times. [volume] (Washington [D.C.]), 12 May 1913. Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress. (chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1913-05-12/ed-...)

Sometimes called the Big Tim Sullivan Association

Timothy Daniel Sullivan (July 23, 1862 – August 31, 1913) was a New York politician who controlled Manhattan's Bowery and Lower East Side districts as a prominent figure within Tammany Hall. He was euphemistically known as "Dry Dollar", as the "Big Feller", and, later, as "Big Tim" (because of his large stature). During the late 19th and early 20th centuries, he controlled much of the city's criminal activities between 14th Street and the Battery in New York City. He is credited as being one of the earliest ward representatives to use his position to enable the activities of criminal street gangs.

The Association quite liked outings to College Point. See some details here: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3682650860/ And since we can see the date on the plate of "6/30/13", here is the report from the next day's New York Times: OUTING MINUS "BIG TIM"; Boweryites Miss Absent Chieftain on Their Annual Excursion" query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9D05E4D71139E6... Highlight of the fun and games was a baseball game of teams comprised of Lean Men versus Fat Men. Read the linked story to see who won.

Looks to me like President Woodrow Wilson's first wife, Ellen Axson Wilson, on the right. Wikipedia article. She died in 1914. I'll let someone else figure out which of the Wilson daughters this is. Wilson's summer home in the first years of his presidency, which this must be from as the first Mrs. Wilson is still alive, was in Cornish, New Hampshire.

Ellen Axson Wilson and her daughter Jessie (for comparison's sake):
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3048509486/]

A story in the New York Times (July 6, 1913) reported that Wilson had seen the New Hampshire summer White House on that day, for the first time ever. On arrival, he kissed his wife, and his daughter, "Miss Eleanor." Eleanor is the girl in the photo. Daughter Jessie arrived later in the evening, with her fiance, Francis Sayre. Daughter Margaret, visiting in Madison, Wisconsin, was not present. Here is the NYT story: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A04E2DC153FE6...

Thanks for helping to sort out who is pictured and likely when. It does appear to be Pres. Wilson with Ellen Axson Wilson and daughter Eleanor. Aha, but which Mrs. Clarence Mackay? www.mackayhistory.com/2_mrs_mackays.html That might be the former Anna Case (1888-1984), second wife of financier Clarence Hungerford Mackay (1874-1938). Anna was a soprano with the Metropolitan Opera, which would make the costume reasonable. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clarence_Mackay The necklace Clarence gave Anna for a wedding gift is in the Smithsonian's Gem and Mineral Collection: gimizu.de/sgmcol/html/mckay.html But on the other hand.... Clarence and Anna didn't meet until 1916, and they didn't actually marry until 1930 (his first wife divorced him in 1914, but he wouldn't remarry while she was still alive). So it could, instead, be Katherine Duer Mackay (1880-1930), also a beauty; Katherine was a suffragette who ran away with Clarence's doctor in 1910, and took their three kids with her.

Grand Duke Michael Mikhailovich of Russia (Russian: Михаил Михайлович; 16 October 1861 – 26 April 1929) was a son of Grand Duke Michael Nicolaievich of Russia and a first cousin of Alexander III of Russia. He followed a military career, but was banished from living in Russia when in 1891 he contracted a morganatic marriage with Countess Sophie of Merenberg. He spent the rest of his life living in exile in England and in the French Riviera, escaping the Russian Revolution. His two daughters married within the British aristocracy. Countess Sophie of Merenberg, Countess de Torby, (1 June 1868 – 14 September 1927) was the eldest daughter of Prince Nikolaus Wilhelm of Nassau and Natalya Alexandrovna Pushkina. She first met John Jacob Astor IV, one of the richest men in the United States, in Bar Harbor, Maine while she was still in school. On September 9, 1911 the eighteen-year-old Madeleine married the forty-seven year old John Jacob Astor in Beechwood, the Astor family's Newport, Rhode Island home. Robley Dunglison Evans (1846-1912), Civil War veteran, commanded a battleship during the Spanish-American War, commanded the Atlantic Fleet from 1905, called "Fighting Bob." There have been two US Navy destroyers named for Evans: www.history.navy.mil/photos/pers-us/uspers-e/rd-evans.htm

The Japanese Admiral at right is not "Yamamota", but rather "Yamamoto". He is not to be confused with Admiral Isoroku Yamamato, famous of WW Two exploits. He is Yamamoto Gonnohyōe, or Admiral Count Yamamoto Gonbee. From wikipedia: "Yamamoto's subsequent rise through the ranks was rapid: rear admiral (1895); vice admiral and Navy Minister (1898). He was raised to the rank of danshaku (baron) under the kazoku peerage system in 1902; and he was promoted to the rank of admiral in 1904. As Minister of the Navy during the Russo-Japanese War, Yamamoto showed strong leadership and was responsible for appointing Tōgō Heihachirō as commander-in-chief of the Combined Fleet. He gave voice to Tōgō's reports when he read his aloud his reports from the war to the assembled Diet.[2] Yamamoto was elevated to hakushaku (count) in 1907. Count Yamamoto served as Prime Minister in 1913-14." (ref. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yamamoto_Gonnohy%c5%8de ) This photograph was almost certainly taken on July 10 or on July 11, 1907. The two admirals met on both those days inthe midst of Admiral Baron Yamamoto's July 1907 trip to the USA. The met at the New York Navy Yard, and at a luncheon at the hotel Astor on July 11. Note the references to Admiral Baron Yamamato in this NYT article of the next day: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D0CE7D7133EE033A... See also the NYT of July 11, 1907: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9405E1DC1738E033A... 1907&st=cse

Charles G. Gates (d. 1913), prominent young Wall Street broker, married his second wife Florence Hopwood of Minneapolis in 1911, shortly after his father, millionaire John Warne Gates. president of Illinois Steel, died in Paris.  (He and first wife, Mary Martin of St. Louis, divorced, also in 1911.)

CG Gates died suddenly, from a heart attack while on a hunting trip in Wyoming in October 1913.  He was 37. His mother, Dellora Baker Gates, survived him.  Florence Hopwood Gates soon married again, in January 1915, to Harold Lee Judd.

Date on photo negative (in reverse) appears to be July 5, 1913. Charles Gilbert Gates was the son of John W. ("Bet A Million") Gates, pioneer manufacturer of barb wire, who (with the help of Judge Elbert Gary) grew the wire manufacturing industry into a monopoly, which became part of Andrew Carnegie's U. S. Steel Corporation. Charles Gates was a free spender, who boasted that he gave away a million dollars a year, just in tips. He was also addicted to speed, and several times raced in private trains across the continent to set speed records for long distance travel. One such exploit took place in July, 1913 -- a fast trip from his home in Minneapolis to New York City, where he had a seat on the Stock Exchange. "The most sensational of all the stories in which Charles G. Gates has figured," said the New York Times in its obituary, "was a report from Minneapolis last July that he had been thrashed in a restaurant by Frank Hopwood, his father-in-law." That report pursued Gates to New York, where on his arrival he denied the story, and said that he would return to Minneapolis and thrash the person who launched the rumor, if he could identify him. Here is the New York Times report of Gates' death, October 29, 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9C02E...

This photo matches others of Charles Gilbert Gates in the Library of Congress collections. An uncropped version of this image was copyrighted in 1903 by someone other than Bain. It was used in 1911 for a news story about Gates traveling from Yuma, AZ to New York on a special train. The date written on a Bain negative may represent the date it was made or it may represent a later date, perhaps when it was acquired or used.  It makes sense that the photo may have been acquired or used to illustrate Gates' exploits in July 1913.  The date on the negative sometimes corresponds to the date it was taken but not always.  In this case the photo was probably taken ten years earlier.  We'll add some information to the description when we update this record.
What a charmer, from the photograph!

The photograph was copyrighted in 1903, so he would have been about 27 when it was taken. He appears to be smoking a cigar: perhaps indicative of a habit which contributed to his fatal heart attack . . . .

By referencing those column bases and other architectural details, NYC historians may be able to pinpoint the photo's exact location.
There is an entry in Wikipedia for him: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Gilbert_Gates

The east Texas "second family" of Gates was from Hemphill, and were abandoned after John W. died, to be left in obscurity (and poverty) when C.G. and his mother returned north. They were left with the name, which was passed down through the generations to follow.

Probably Soroku Ebara, envoy from Japan sent to try to ease tension over California's "Alien Land Law" of 1913: "The appeal from the Japanese residents of California was so insistent and the excitement of the public opinion of Japan so great, that the political parties, the Christian organizations and the business interests of Japan, all decided to send representative men to California to counsel moderation and to give comfort to the compatriots who appeared to be made the object of economic persecution. At the same time such men sent from Japan could study the situa- tion on the spot and report upon the causes of the perennial outbursts of anti- Japanese sentiment and point out the way to the possible solution of the difficulty. With such an object in view, Mr. Soroku Ebara, then a member of the House of Representatives and later of the House of Peers of the Imperial Diet, was selected by the Seiyukai, or the Constitutional party which has been dominant in the domestic politics of Japan for fully a decade." www.archive.org/stream/growthofinternat00miyaiala/growtho...

This photograph appears to have been copied by the Bain News Service. The smudge on the lower right corner is where the Elliott signature appeared. The negative is marked with two dates in the upper left corner. A Bain file print of this photo is annotated "June 18, 1913 To proceed against New Haven Road for Violation of Anti-Trust Act" so the 6/30/1913 date may relate to this event. The second date, 1/30/24, corresponds to the date that Gregory was named by President Coolidge as Special Council for the Oil Inquiry to investigate what was later to be referred to as the Teapot Dome Scandal. We'll add Gregory's fuller name and the date to the description when we update it.

Daniel Sickles (1819-1914) lost his leg during the Civil War. Colorful character: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Sickles Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Disability History, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

Judging by the hat and the solder escorting him, I'd guess that he's at the Grand Reunion of 1913, held at Gettysburg Pennsylvania, to mark the 50th anniversary of the battle. Sickles lost his leg, and a large portion of his command, there. He donated his lost limb to a medical museum in Washington, where he'd visit it from time to time. 
Earlier in life, he shot and killed Philip Barton Key, Francis Scott Key's son, who was having an affair with his wife. I believe he was the first American to use the temporary insanity defense.

Mrs. Wilmerding is Eleanor Earle Wilmerding, who was Sickles' housekeeper and mistress. She lived with him in New York; his estranged wife and adult son lived in a nearby hotel when they were in town. Mrs. Wilmerding controlled who visited SIckles in his later years, and accompanied him on his rare public appearances (at 93, he was no longer capable of making speeches). Surprisingly, she died before him, in February 1914--he passed away a few weeks later, in April. www.sicklesatgettysburg.com/Sickles_Biography.html

I think MDRails could well be correct about this being related to the reunion of July 1913, especially because of the army uniform of his escort. Thanks to everyone for their insightful comments about General Daniel Edgar Sickles and Eleanor Earle Wilmerding.  The photograph was likely taken at the Gettysburg reunion in July 1913.  The Library of Congress has a print submitted for Copyright on August 11, 1913 showing the same scene and stating that it was taken at Gettysburg.  We will update our records.

At Gettysburg, the central day of commemoration in 1913 was July 3. The negative of this photo bears the date July 4, 1913. Thomas Keneally, author of "Schindler's List," has written a biography of General Sickles ("American Scoundrel," 2002), in which he states that Sickles and Mrs. Wilmerding stayed overnight at Gettysburg, so that Sickles could hear the speech by President Woodrow Wilson on July 4. Therefore we may deduce that this photo shows the pair at the Gettysburg depot later on that date, preparing to entrain for the journey back to New York.

This photo was taken before Parliament burned down. The peace tower is different now.

This is the former centre block of the Canadian Parliament Buildings.  With the exception of the parliamentary library (the conical rooftop seen in the rear of the building), it was completely desstroyed by a fire on February 2, 1916.  A new and larger centre block was rebuilt on the same site.  It was completed in 1928.  In the meantime, Parliament met at the National Museum, located at the other end of Metcalfe Street.

Large version and geodata here:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/trialsanderrors/3640413531]

The conical portion of the parliament buildings (i.e., the portion furthest to the right) is the parliamentary library.  It is the only original portion of the building still standing.  The rest of the building was destroyed by fire on February 2, 1916, and was replaced by a newer structure completed in 1928.
In the foreground is the entrance to the Rideau Canal

And Yes, not much has changed since then.  That little building with the red roof was the former "Parliament Pumphouse".  Its long gone, but its complete foundation AND mini tunnel remain and its quite cool to look at and take photos of.  Just a lost piece of the city that was.  When Parliament was rebuilt in 1916, the plans called for the pumphouse to be moved next to where the supreme court stands and to have everything route that way instead.  That one is still there now.

@ LOC: There is a spelling error in the Detroit Publishing Company's title for this photochrom (no. “54002”). This s/b the Van Horne Range. There seemingly is little doubt the range was named for Sir William Van Horne. There are conflicting references as to who actually named the range for him. ● “In 1885-86, Dr. Vaux, the Alpine climber of Philadelphia, named the Van Horne Range of mountains in British Columbia for Sir William C. Van Horne” of Canadian Pacific Railway fame. —The Life and Work of Sir William Van Horne ● Sir William Cornelius Van Horne, KCMG (1843-1915) was President of Canadian Pacific Railway from 1888 to 1899. He is most famous for overseeing the major construction of the first Canadian transcontinental Railway. He was was also key in building the Cuba Railway in 1901. –Excerpted Wikipedia ● Parks Canada Map [PDF] Yoho National Park, with Van Horne Range identified. ● “Dr. Vaux, the Alpine climber of Philadelphia,” referred to above is likely George Vaux Jr. (1863-1927), or William S. Vaux Jr. (1872-1908). Along with their sister, Mary Vaux (1860-1940), the Vaux family of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania were photographers, mountaineers and scientists. They saw the mountains of western Canada for the first time in 1887. Mary would later marry Dr. Charles D. Walcott, the noted geologist and invertebrate paleontologist, and former Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. [1] ● Van Horne Range (82N) – Description of Van Horne Range and William Cornelius Van Horne. “The name was chosen for the range by George Dawson (1849-1901)”.

Date inscribed on negative (in reverse) is July 10, 1913.
McGraw was already a manager in 1913.  Must have been hitting balls for fielding practice.

John McGraw was a Baseball pioneer in many ways. He developed many of the fundamentals of the game that are second nature today. As a player and manager he developed many of the strategies of the game still in use, such as the ‘squeeze-bunt’ and the ‘hit-and-run’. John McGraw asked that the pitchers and catchers report first to spring training, weeks ahead of other players, as they always seem to be the most ‘out-of-shape.’ and when once asked about a substitute hitter in a game, he described the man as “good in the pinch,” leading to use of the term ‘pinch-hitter.’ His New York Giants teams won 10 National League pennants, 3 World Series, and finished second 11 times. His record for most wins as a National League manager still stands at 2,669 victories. He was an incredible judge of baseball talent, and his player development program made the Giants perennial contenders. Health issues forced John McGraw into retirement mid-way through the 1932 season, yet he was able to manage the National League team in the first-ever All-Star Game in 1933.

Interesting that the majority of the images here have players choking up on the bat?

In the "deadball" era, the ball was softer, mushier, and didn't carry off the bat like it does today.  It was largely futile for batters to hold the bat at the bottom and swing with all their might.  Choking up on the bat gave them much greater bat control so they could find success by "hitting them where they ain't."

Some information is at diglib.princeton.edu/ead/getEad?id=ark:/88435/7h149p89n "Prince Roland Bonaparte was a grand nephew of Napoleon Bonaparte. He had no royal aspirations; instead he turned to study science, geography, geology, botany, ethnology, and anthropology. He focused on the documentation of physical characteristics, in particular the shape and dimension of the skull as a way to established relations between the human races. He perceived photography as a scientific tool for preserving data from his expeditions, and used it to document the American Indians, Surinamese, Hottentots, and other ethnic groups. Bonaparte was president of the "Société de géographie" (France) from 1910 till his death, and was also a member, then president, of the "Académie des sciences" (France)." He may have been in the news in summer 1913 because, according to query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B03E6D71F3AE633A... he was a host of a banquet in Paris for Admiral Peary.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Abernathy_Boys_of_Oklahoma Louis Abernathy (1900-?) and Temple Abernathy (1904-1986) were children from Oklahoma who without adult supervision took several cross-country trips. On one trip they rode their motorcycle from Oklahoma to Manhattan in 1910 when they were 10 and 6 years old.

New York Times story, June 1, 1910, reports the boys, then 9 and 6, rode horses all the way from Oklahoma to Washington, D. C., where President William Howard Taft greeted them at the White House: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9400E... New York Times story, June 4, 1910, reports boys' reception at Capitol building, where they were brought onto the floor of the House and greeted by Speaker Joseph Cannon: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9F07E4D81530E2... New York Times story, June 7, 1910, reports boys have left Washington, headed for Baltimore: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=990DE2DF1E39E3... New York Times story, June 9, 1910, reports boys and their horses in Baltimore as they journey from Washington, D. C. to New York City. Their mother died three years earlier, but their father, U. S. Marshall John ("Jack") Abernathy is interviewed -- one of Teddy Roosevelt's Rough Riders, and a famous Oklahoma wolf catcher, he has killed 400 wolves with his bare hands: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9F02EFDF1E39E3... New York Times story, June 10, 1910, places the boys in Wilmington, Delaware, still headed north: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B01E6D71530E2... New York Times story, June 13, 1910, reports that the boys have joined their father in New York City, and occupied the Rockefeller pew at First Baptist Church: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C01E3D71530E2...
Temple Abernathy's widow, Alta Abernathy, wrote "Bud and Me," a book about their adventures as told by Temple. Bud was Temple's name for his older brother, Louis Abernathy.

This is the 50th anniversary reunion at Gettysburg in July 1913. This particular place was the siteof a reenactment of Pickett's Charge at Bloody Angle. It is not "Senator" Moore. The original caption is incorrect. It is not Bloody Angel, it is "Bloody Angle". J. Hampton Moore, shown speaking stridently in the photograph was the congressional Representative for Pennsylvania from November 6, 1906 to January 4, 1920. See offical biography here: bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=M000906 See a comparison photograph at FindAGrave here: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=12893 The Battle of Gettysburg ran from July 1 to July 3, 1863. There is a mirror date scratched on the plate " 7/3/13 " July 3, 1913 being the 50th anniversary of the conclusion of the battle. It was a terribly hot day in Gettysburg, as you can see with some veterans sheltering under the shade of parasols. The story of the reenactment is here, in the New York Times of July 4, 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9F01E0DD153FE6... "The Bloody Angle is formed by a break in the line of a stone fence." This area today: www.flickr.com/photos/cwpt/2197122471/in/photostream/

Hi Gluecrue. There was indeed much controversy in his day as to whether Frederick Cook was the first person to reach the North Pole, or in fact did at all. The discussion surrounding Cook's activities (and Robert Peary, another Arctic explorer claiming to have reached the Pole) was widely covered by the newspapers during this time, and, if you're interested, can be explored further by searching for these men in the Chronicling America web site. See chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85052114/1909-09-18/ed-... for an example of contemporary coverage of the controversy.

There is beautiful reprint of an original book written by Jack Villas for his children in 1929, edited and augmented by Rustic Books www.rusticbooks.net/rustic_reflections.htm#aviator . It is ISBN 978-09771137-2-9 Cheers Kees

The hull of this very aircraft still exists.  It is a part of the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum collection (Inventory Number: A19490022000).  Jack Vilas donated the hull of his Curtiss Model E Flying Boat to the museum in 1949.

Great that Vilas preserved this early flying boat hull during all these years. So it still exists. It must be one of the few original flying boat hulls from the period. Pity that it is far away from the public, in storage. Have you ever seen a picture of it, so the condition and / or the markings of the hull can be seen?

Cheers

Kees

Here's a link to a recent photo of the hull. Vilas apparently painted the hull green sometime after this flight. No markings are visible in the photo posted by the Smithsonian. collections.nasm.si.edu/code/emuseum.asp?profile=objects&...

Thanks for the information. The hull looks good for a piece dating from 1913 and having been stored in a barn or something during 36 years (!)

Cheers

might be this guy: WINSLOW, Samuel Ellsworth, a Representative from Massachusetts; born in Worcester, Mass., April 11, 1862; attended the public schools; was graduated from Worcester Classical High School in 1880, from Williston Seminary, Easthampton, Mass., in 1881, and from Harvard University in 1885; engaged in the manufacture of skates; appointed as a colonel on the staff of Governor Brackett in 1890; chairman of the Republican city committee of Worcester 1890-1892; chairman of the Republican State committee in 1893 and 1894; delegate to the Republican National Convention in 1908; elected as a Republican to the Sixty-third and to the five succeeding Congresses (March 4, 1913-March 3, 1925); chairman, Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce (Sixty-seventh and Sixty-eighth Congresses); was not a candidate for renomination in 1924; appointed by President Coolidge in 1926 as a member of the United States Board of Mediation, for the disposition of disputes between carriers and their employees, and was subsequently chosen chairman, serving until 1934; moved in 1935 to Worcester, Mass., where he died July 11, 1940; remains were cremated and the ashes interred in Hope Cemetery. bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=W000639 This site has another photo of Winslow, seems to be the congressman: images.google.com/imgres?imgurl=http://www.firstworldwar.... Mr. & Mrs. Shepard are attending a polo match at Meadow Brook Field. The Newport Cup, effectively the polo championship of the world, was played there on June 14, 1913. America defeated England. From the New York Times of the following day: " Mr. and Mrs. Finley J. Shepard (Miss Helen Gould) also paid their first visit to Meadow Brook. After they had run the gauntlet of cameras, they sat with Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Gould in a grandstand box. Mrs. Shepard wore a blue poplin dress topped with a blush straw hat which had a single red rose." There were many other society types there whom were fully described in the article: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9D05E... I believe that the listing of society attendees will help to match up with other photographs taken on the same day.

The photo was taken at the White House in Washington, D. C., in June, 1912, when Taft was the incumbent President. This was his second experience of the notification ritual. The committee had traveled from the Republican National Convention in Chicago, where Taft had been nominated for a second term. In the era before a candidate attended the convention in person, this was his ceremonial acceptance.

But of course, Taft went down to defeat in November. Woodrow Wilson, the Democratic candidate, was victorious, and Theodore Roosevelt, leader of the Bull Moose Party, came in second.

In the Bain Company files at LOC is a photo of Taft's 1908 notification, in Cincinnati (his home town) -- but LOC has not yet posted that photo on Flickr.

Charles Becker (July 26, 1870 – July 30, 1915) was a New York City police officer in the 1890s-1910s and who was tried, convicted and executed for ordering the murder of a Manhattan gambler, Herman Rosenthal in the Becker-Rosenthal trial. Becker was the first American police officer to receive the death penalty for murder. The scandal that surrounded his arrest, conviction, and execution was one of the most important in Progressive Era New York in the 1890s to 1910s. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Becker

Harry Angstrom:

Thanks for the tip! It seems likely this is dancer and dance instructor Louis Chalif, so we will likely add that to the record when we update.

Louis Harvy Chalif wrote such books as "Russian Festivals and Costumes for Pageant and Dance" (1921) and "The Chalif Textbook of Dancing," which can both be found on Googlebooks. His career is discussed in Mirjana Lausevic, Balkan Fascination: Creating an Alternative Music Culture in America (Oxford UP 2007): 95-105. He seems to have been involved somewhat with the settlement movement's efforts to include folk culture and physical activity in urban education; he died in 1948.
Poor pass of the baton in the Ladies' 4X100 yds at the Los Angeles Olympics
There's a river in the background. This is probably the practice session for an outdoor dance exhibition at a college festival somewhere.
I started an entry for him in Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_Harvy_Chalif

The dancers' costumes here resemble Greek national folk attire, or even historic Greek military costume. Richard, in his Wikipedia entry, notes that in 1920 Chalif published a book on Greek dancing.

Chalif's advertisement in the New-York Tribune (November 24, 1912) emphasized that he taught "Classical and Esthetic Greek and National Dancing."

Charles H. Betts, editor of the Lyons (N.Y.) Republican, was a commentator on political issues who conducted a correspondence with Theodore Roosevelt. In 1913 he published a book, THE NAKED TRUTH, Vital Issues Before the Country Clearly Analyzed and Discussed. The text was a speech he had delivered in 1912, during the U. S. Presidential campaign. The text is now available on Google Books, where it is accompanied by this photograph.

Christ on Crutches: The addition of the 'Migrant Mother' by Lange and the other selected images from the black-and-white negatives of the Farm Security Administration/Office of War Information Collection is our first foray into sharing that part of the FSA/OWI Collection on Flickr. The entire black-and-white portion of the FSA/OWI Collection, numbering over 171,000 negatives, is available in the Prints & Photographs Online Catalog, including this one of Allie Mae Burroughs and others of the rest of the Burroughs family. (More information about, as well as a link to search within the black-and-white negatives of the FSA/OWI Collection can be found here). We are exploring ways to share more of the FSA/OWI Collection, as well as other collections from our holdings, in Flickr and are glad to hear there is an interest for more of these historic images!

This photo by Dorothea Lange was part of the Family of Man exhibit by Edward Steichen in the 1950's for MoMA. The exhibit was published in catalog from in various editions. Perhaps this has bearing on copyright? en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Family_of_Man My family owned one of the exhibit catalogs and that is where I recall this seeing and growing up with this picture. However, it may be that Steichen culled from the Library of Congress for the original exhibit?

Dorothea Lange took the photograph on assignment for the Farm Security Administration, i.e. it was "work for hire" for the U.S. Government. Since the U.S. Government cannot hold copyright the picture is in the public domain and can be re-published by anyone (including the MoMA).

interesting how Lange missed critical focus on the face of the woman. look at the image at full size and you will find that the sharpest area of the image is in the boy's hair.

andrew.allen97 I think that's an illusion because the hair is more contrasty. Mrs. Thompson's hand is sharp, as is her shirt collar, and the elbow of the boy on the right. When you consider Lange was hand-holding a large format camera fifteen feet away in a muddy field, I think she did bloody well to get anything in focus!

Actually, there is no boy in the picture :)

Having spent an hour plus cleaning this picture, I can say with some authority that the area most in focus is her cleavage... (well, actually the checkered shirt she's wearing). That's something you'll notice if you print the picture at about 25x20" (at 300ppi), or about five times as big as the original.

well the child's hair (on the right) is on the same plane as the shirt, correct? and wouldn't that make the face of the woman in front of the focal plane? and yes, arturo, i didn't take that into account. that is quite impressive.

regardless, my point was that the woman's face is not quite in focus. I'm wondering if it was deliberate or not.

great photo nonetheless

Possibly, it's just easier to locate the focal plane based on patterns like the checkers on the shirt or the knitting of the cardigan than hair... 

As Arturo said, with the technical limitations of the day and the context of the shoot (Florence Owen was less a willing participant than a passive subject, and Lange likely didn't want to overstay her welcome) it's unlikely that the focus was deliberately off.

amazing !!!!!!

…trialsanderrors wrote "This particular view, with the girls turning their backs to the camera, was arranged by Dorothea Lange." What is your source for that statement? I don't believe Lange asked them to pose, if that's what you are implying. The removal of the thumb in later versions of the print is one thing, but Lange was a documentary photographer. She said of her approach to her work "What I photograph, I do not molest or tamper with or arrange. I try to make a picture as part of its surroundings, as having roots". The children may have "posed" themselves as Lange took the five photos, getting nearer to Mrs Thompson each time. History doesn't record any actual dialogue between Lange or her subjects. She took the photos, and then drove away.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/artysmokes/] If this is a scan of the negative, then it's the negative of a copy of the original, with the thumb burned out. What happened to the original negative? The thumb was burned out of the negative some time after the original prints were made, so this is a scan of the negative as it appears now. A print of the original version was discovered only recently and is part of the LoC collection. History doesn't record any actual dialogue between Lange or her subjects. Actually, Florence Owen's children claim that Lange promised her mom that the pictures would not be published (a pretty implausible claim, given Lange's job description). What is your source for that statement? I don't believe Lange asked them to pose, if that's what you are implying. I'll have to get back to you on the source (there are dozens discussing the picture and the belated response of the family), but her statement can hardly be taken at face value. Lange took some 4000 pictures for the RA/FSA alone, and quite a few show clear signs of interaction with her subjects. Lange had a reputation of being able to make herself nearly invisible if she wanted to, but clearly the Owens family noticed and responded to her. By the time Lange took the "Migrant Mother" picture, she was close enough so that the girls could simply stay out of the picture if they didn't want to appear in it (as some of them they did on the earlier shots). For them to get back into the picture and then to turn their heads is not a plausible scenario if the agreed-upon sequence is indeed the correct one.

…trialsanderrors wrote "The thumb was burned out of the negative some time after the original prints were made." Just a technique question, but how does one do that? I know how dodging and burning is done during the enlarging/printing process, but how does someone "burn" the negative?

I profess ignorance on the technical part of the question. The LoC description states "The negative was retouched in the 1930s to erase the thumb holding a tent pole in lower right hand corner." — "Burning" might not be the correct term...

From what I know, they used a direct positive paper that was developed in a single bath developer/fixer and the images were then superficially rinsed in a bucket of water. All those street photos are probably laced with  chemicals, but miraculously many have survived well. The images were often of poor contrast. 

Later photographers used print paper and then would first make a paper negative and then re-photograph using an easel attachment on the front of the camera to make a positive. 

There are still photographers in places like Afghanistan doing this, but their numbers are dwindling due to the proliferation of digital photography.  The LA Times recently ran an article on them.

For those of us who are not familiar with America's love affair with our cars, the Pixar movie for kids called "Cars" was based on meticulous research into life on Route 66.  The "Cozy Cone Motel" someone referred to was just one of those many points.  The wigwam motels in Holbrooke, AZ and Rialto, CA are still in operation  but barely.  I took my kids to stay overnight at the Holbrook establishment.  They looked for Lightning McQueen, Sally and Mater until late at night.

With friends, a bunch of us make the pilgrimage  to WWV#2 nearly every year. It's goofy fun to land in this dry county and take over for a couple of nights. Gather up ur friends and go sleep in a wigwam. Take plenty of firewood for the fire ring and have a cookout in the shelter behind. But  save one evening for dinner up the road in Munfordville at Big Bubba Buck's Belly Bustin' Bliss BBQ. Yummy. Oh, be sure to take your own booze cause the nearest is in Bowling Green and that's a drive. The Cave City, KY exit for the motel is also the exit for Mammoth Cave, we've done it and their various tours are set up for adults and kids. We always have great fun taking this trip and I'm sure you would, too!

The name of this cemetery is St. Micheal's.  It lies on the sloping side of a low moutain on the south side of Bethlehem Pennsylvania.  This was the side of the town where the mill stood.  It was the side that the workers lived on as you can see by the row homes in the picture.  As the plant closed and the jobs disappeared many families were forced to leave.  Shops and lunch counters closed with no noon rush to keep them open.  The south side became run down, buildings sat empty and this cemetery was neglected and vandalized.  

Behind where Evans stood to shoot this image, the graves continue up into the tree line.  Many do not contain a word of English, baring testament to the various ethnic groups that had come here to work at the steel.  Some, such as a plain cross cut from sheet metal show just how hard some people were struggling.

I have always been intrigued and saddened by the downfall of Bethlehem Steel and all it symbolized in this great nation.  When my horse was stabled at Penn National in 2009 I stopped early one morning (enroute from central NJ) as the sun was rising to video the blast furnaces and empty buildings.  I did a short narration so that my children could see and understand the blood, sweat, and tears that built this country.  May the efforts put forth there and the hard working people in that cemetary not be forgotten.

«I was just my fathers son
Saving my money
Dreaming of glory
Twitching like a finger
On the trigger of a gun
Leaving nothing but the dead and dying
Back in my little town
Nothing but the dead and dying
Back in my little town»
Paul Simon

So, according to Wikipedia, these were pretty much relics by 1910 - which is why there are so many people swimming in the ocean outside of the machines.  Ugh.  What a hassle.

Remember the gas combustion engine, and how a single person would fire up one of them to transport themselves five miles to an office?  It would be parked in huge specially created buildings that had no other purpose than to store the machine for the day.  At the end of the work period, the individual would fire the thing up and transport themselves back to their home where the machine would sit in a specially created structure until it was used the next day.  At one time the economy of the entire United States and many countries in Europe and Asia were dependent upon the manufacture and sales of these machines.
A totally different concept of 4wheeldrives on the beach nowadays.

The USS Sylph was the third Presidential Yacht. Purchased during the war with Spain for $50,000, the 123 foot vessel was commissioned at the Norfolk Navy Yard in August, 1898. McKinley was the first President to use the Sylph. President Roosevelt made frequent cruises on her to his summer place at Oyster Bay, New York, and President Taft used this vessel off the New England coast during the summers of his administration. [1] [2]

Yes, "High Society" is a wonderful movie. In August, 1956, when I was 13, I sailed to Europe with my parents and little sister on a Dutch ship, the RMS Maasdam. The crossing took nine days. There wasn't much for a kid to do: no TV, but the ship did have a couple of new movies that they showed over and over -- "High Society," and Alec Guinness in "The Ladykillers." By voyage's end, I had memorized them both, and probably another that I don't remember now. Grace Kelley and I were in love, but she didn't know it.

I recently researched The Sylph. I remember her when she carried my Aunt from the Battery at the southern tip of Manhattan, NYC. to Sea Gate, Coney Island, Brooklyn, New York City. Sea Gate was a gated community on Coney Island, at the western tip of Long Island, in Brooklyn. I remember, every weekday evening, the passengers walking by our house which was just a block from the pier where she docked in Sea Gate. www.navsource.org/archives/12/1305.htm Patrol Yacht: Built by John Roach and Co., Chester, PA Acquired by the Navy in June 1898 Commissioned USS Sylph 18 August 1989 at the Norfolk Navy Yard for use as a Presidential Yacht Designated a Patrol Yacht, PY-5, 17 July 1921 Decommissioned, 27 April 1929 at the Norfolk Navy Yard Struck from the Navy list, 29 April 1929 Sold, 26 November 1929 to Mr. Frank B. Clair of Brooklyn, NY (Mr. Clair was reportedly an ex-bootlegger). Mr. Clair and his partner Captain John Nugent converted her into a party fishing boat and operated her from Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, NY. The Sylph fished from Sheepshead Bay until April 1939, when she changed her business and ran a ferry service from Sea Gate, Brooklyn to the Battery in Manhattan. In 1941, her owners defaulted on the mortgage held by the Worthington Diesel Company and they took possession of the vessel Fate unknown. Specifications: Displacement 152 t. Length 123' 8" Beam 20 ' Draft 7' 6" Speed 15 kts. Complement: 1905 - 31 Armament: 1905 - One 6-pounder Propulsion: One 550ihp vertical triple expansion steam engine, one shaft 1935 - Replaced by a 400hp Worthington diesel engine. "This rare 1909 photo of the "SYLPH" depicts her during her tenure as the official United States Presidential Yacht for President Theodore Roosevelt. The US Navy originally purchased the "SYLPH" in June 1898 from her builder, John Roach & Co., Chester, PA, and they commissioned the vessel as a Presidential Yacht on August 18, 1898 at the Norfolk Navy Yard. The "SYLPH" served in this capacity for Presidents McKinley (1898-1901), Roosevelt (1901-1909), Taft (1909-1913) and Wilson (1913-1921). In 1921, the Navy re-designated her as Patrol Yacht "PY-5" and she sailed on the Potomac and Anacostia Rivers. In 1925, she was permanently moored at the Washington Navy Yard, where she remained until her decommissioning in April 1929. Frank B. Clair of Brooklyn, New York purchased her in November 1929 (Mr. Clair was reportedly an ex-bootlegger.) Mr. Clair and his partner Captain John Nugent converted her into a party fishing boat and operated her from Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, NY. Here she is in Sheepshead bay circa 1935: In 1935, her boiler failed and she was re-powered with a 400 HP Worthington diesel engine. Also during 1935, Jeremiah 'Jerry' Driscoll purchased Mr. Clair's share of the business. She continued fishing from Sheepshead Bay until April 1939, when she changed her business and ran a ferry service from Sea Gate, Brooklyn to the Battery in Manhattan. Here she is as a commuter ferry circa 1938: Alas, in 1941, her owners defaulted on the mortgage held by the Worthington Diesel Company and they took possession of the vessel. The "SYLPH" is the only vessel in history to go from presidents to porgies."

puzzlemaster: thanks for the information which will be useful to update our records. However, there seems to be a discrepancy in the year he was born. You have January 9, 1885 while in the same link that you provided it has his birth date as being 1887, www.earlyaviators.com/ewood.htm. Where did you find the date of his birth? Thanks.

I got his birth date from his passport application of 1913 which I found in US Passport Applications 1789-1925 at ancestry.com  The application, which is signed by Mr Wood, gives his birth date as January 9, 1885.  The application appears to have been filled out by someone other than the signatory, however, so perhaps it is not as reliable as it first appears.

So I went back and searched for more evidence.   The 1900 US Census of Bible Grove IL includes a Clyde M Wood, son of Leander Wood, who was born in January 1885.  The 1910 Census of the same place also has " C M Wood, aged 25, teacher" who appears to be the same individual.

Might be "Ginocchio"? "Ginocchio" gets far more google hits as a surname than "Inocchio." (Ginocchio means "knee" in Italian.) In the October 22, 1910 edition of Foreign Aviation News there's an item:
A Bleriot for the Italian Army During Saturday afternoon the Italian officer Ginocchio was flying at Etampes for two hours on his two-seated Bleriot with a passenger, the height ranging up to 500 metres. On the previous day the machine had been tested by Lemartin, who was aloft for an hour and a half, and flew three times over the town of Etampes, his greatest height being 800 metres.
Found here: www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1910/1910 - 0873.html

If you put 'Ginocchio' back into the searchbox in the FlightGlobal 'Archive' section it reveals a Captain Ginocchio in charge of the first Italian Government Sea Plane Station at Venice about 1912.A further Google search records an early overwater record flight Venice-Trieste-Venice (256km) by Ginocchio and Chet. I put Ginocchio into the LOC photo search box and got 'Captain Ginocchio's Aeroplane' memory.loc.gov/service/pnp/ggbain/13400/13494v.jpg a photo of a little sea plane at Venice, Italy (and there is a section of that photo(church tower) in the lower LH corner of this one...which may be of a Wright type 2-seater trainer?) .....well done 'pennylrichardsca' for knowing some Italian The Flightglobal archive is every page of 100years of the UK magazine Flight scanned, digitized, fully searchable and swept by Google. 'Foreign Aviation News' was a section heading in Flight magazine
